section.title: Accessing System Administration Functions
section.para: The Kuali Open Library Environment (OLE) enables users with proper authorization to perform powerful functions that affect the entire system. These functions, which are accessible via the Admin menu tab, allow you to:

listitem.para: Support the Kuali Identity Management (KIM) module and implement security based on accounting line attributes
Define basic types of location and reference information
Control the running of batch jobs
Support the Kuali Enterprise Workflow (KEW) module and
Enable authorized users to perform a variety of other functional and technical activities.

note.para: Only members of OLE-SYS Manager and KR-SYS Technical Administrator roles may initiate most documents in the Admin Menu. Other users may look up values from the lookup screens but may not be able to access other options at all.

section.title: Batch Processes Administrative Documents

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch Processes Links

section.para: The Batch Framework submenu allows you to perform a variety of functional and technical activities that process cataloging records in batch.

The top section of the Batch Processes submenu allows users to manage importing of order records, invoices, patrons, bibliographic records, locations, and serial records. It also allows users to batch export and batch delete records and manages the claim reports. The OLE FS Batch section controls many of the batch processes that occur for financial processes and OLE workflows. It also includes the Deliver Batch Job which creates notices for patrons.

section.title: Batch File Type

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch File Type
> Batch File Type Lookup

section.para: The Batch File Type is a maintenance document used to support batch process profile.

note.para: Batch File Types cannot be edited via the interface. Technical assistance is required to add new or edit existing batch file types.

mediaobject.alt: Batch File Type Lookup Screen with Search Results

section.para: As a function of OLE, you may search for batch file types. Execute a blank search to review the available batch file types.

section.title: Batch Process

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch Process
> Batch Process

note.para: Please click here for technical documentation.

section.para: The Batch Process interface, available from the Admin menu, allows staff to run import and export jobs via the OLE user interface. Once the job has run, staff may receive notifications of completion, view reports and, for importing, make changes to records as necessary.

section.title: Process Overview
section.para: Open the Batch Process interface from the Admin tab.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Interface

listitem.para: Enter a name to distinguish your batch process. This field is not required but it will be helpful to identify the batch process. If left blank, the profile name chosen and a number is used by OLE.
Choose the Batch Process Type from the dropdown menu.

Once a Batch Process Type has been selected, the Batch Process Profile Name field displays. Begin typing the profile name and a list of options will appear. Enter “*” (asterisk) to display the complete list. Select the Profile you wish to use.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Interface: Batch Process Profile Name field

listitem.para: Modify the batch size if necessary. This is the number of records to import or export per batch.
For example, if you are exporting a database of seven million records, you might specify a batch size of one million and OLE will process the output in batches of one million.

However if you are importing records and you specify a lesser number of records to import than what exists in your file, the Batch Process will only import the specified number of records and not the full amount in your file.
If you wish to receive the batch process job report via email, enter your email in Send Job Report To.
If you do not want to receive email notifications, you may also check the listing of job outputs from the Batch Process Job Details interface (see below).
With the exception of Claim Report depending on the Batch Process Type (auto-populated when the Batch Process Profile Name is selected), an Input Section or an Output Section will appear.
Output Section is made available for exporting records types. Select the Output Format (MARC or MARCXML) from the drop down.
Enter the Output File Name, a name given to the file.

note.para:
A note on naming the Output File:
If a "Batch Process Name" is specified, and no "Output File Name" is specified, the batch process name is used for the filename.
If an "Output File Name" is specified, and no "Batch Process Name" is given, the "Output File Field" is used for the filename.
If a "Batch Process Name" is specified, and a filename is given in the "Output File Name" field, the "Output File Name" field is used to generate the filename.
If a file name containing a space is entered in either the "Output File Name" field or the "Batch Process Name" field on the Batch Process screen, although the file will appear normal in the directory display (accessed from Batch Process Job Details > View Job Report > View Export Path), the link to download the file will break off the filename at the first space, with no extension.
This is a known bug to be fixed in a future release. See OLE-6603.
Exported file location will be: export/[batch_process_profile or user_specified_location]/[job_name or job [batch_id]]- [start timestamp] [-part#]. [extension]

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Interface with Output Section (For Batch Exports)

listitem.para:
Input Section is made available for most importing record types. Select Browse... (or Choose File depending on your browser) to search for the file from your local machine.
All EDI Invoice loads require the file extension to be .edi. If it is not, the workaround is to rename the file.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Interface with Input Section (For Importing Bib Records

listitem.para: Input Section for Order Records requires you to choose both a MARC and EDI file, unless the Order Import Profile you chose is marked "MARC only".

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Interface with Input Section (For MARC and EDI files)

listitem.para:
Select Run Now and click Submit
to begin the job immediately.
Alternatively, you may select Schedule to schedule the job (see instructions below).

If you have not scheduled the job for a later time, the Batch Process Job Details page will open in a new tab or window. This interface allows you to review the report, stop, pause, or restart the job.

note.para: For additional information on Batch Process Job Details, see Batch Process Job Details

listitem.para: To Review jobs that are scheduled, reschedule or remove the job from OLE, see Batch Process Job Schedule.

note.para: For additional information on Batch Process Job Schedule, see Batch Process Job Schedule

section.title: Scheduling a Batch Process
section.para: If you select schedule to schedule the Batch Process job, an additional tab will appear to assist in the scheduling process.

listitem.para: You may choose to schedule by Cron Expression. Select the radio button next to Cron Expression and enter the expression in the available text box. For example, "0 0 * * * ?" will export data hourly.

note.para: For more information about Cron expressions in OLE, see Job Cron Expression - controlling the frequency/schedule of job execution.

listitem.para: You may also choose the radio button Schedule to manually enter when the job should occur. You will have two options:

One Time: Enter the date or search for it from the calendar icon
and time for the job to begin.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Process: Schedule Tab set to schedule a one time job

listitem.para: Recurring: Select the schedule type Daily, Weekly or Monthly.
If you selected the Schedule Type Daily, enter the time for the job to begin.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Process: Schedule Tab set to schedule a daily recurring job

listitem.para: If you selected the Schedule Type Weekly, enter the time for the job to begin and check the box for the days of the week that the job should run.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Process: Schedule Tab set to schedule a weekly recurring job

listitem.para: If you selected the Schedule Type Monthly, enter the time for the job to begin, select the calendar date (for example, 23 for the 23rd day of each month), and enter the number of months that should elapse before the job runs again (for example, you may set the job to run every 3 or 6 months).

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Process: Schedule Tab set to schedule a monthly recurring job

section.para:
Once your schedule has been determined, click Submit
.
To see the details of the batch process, including the percent completed and the job report, go to the Batch Process Job Details.

note.para: For more information about Batch Process Job Details, see the section below.

section.title: Scheduling a full dump of the database then incremental exports
section.para: First, create the full batch export profile and run the batch process job.

listitem.para: Search for the batch process profile name that will export full records.

note.para: To make a batch process profile, see below.

listitem.para: Adjust the batch size as needed.
Select the output format.
Enter a file name in the Output filename.
Verify that the radio button Run Now is chosen.
Click Submit to run the full dump.

section.para: Next, create the incremental and schedule it to run daily at preferred time.

listitem.para: Search for the batch process profile name that will export incremental records. A separate profile is needed for this.

note.para: To make a batch process profile, see below.

listitem.para: Adjust the batch size as needed.
Select the output format.
Enter a file name in the Output filename.
Select the radio button Schedule and schedule the preferred time. The job will pick up changes that exist since the job's creation.

note.para: For more information about scheduling a job, see the Scheduling a Batch Process section above.

listitem.para: Click Submit to start the schedule.

section.title: Scheduling a full dump followed by daily incrementals
section.para: To schedule a full dump and then have daily incrementals, create two separate profiles - one for the full dump and one for the incremental. Using the created profiles, run the full export immediately followed by the scheduled incremental export. Schedule the incremental export to run after 'x' amount of time (6pm every evening for example). The first incremental export will be useless. However after the incremental runs the second time and after every 'x' amount of time following, it will export the records changed from the time it was scheduled.

listitem.para: If items are created through Batch Process (in BIB MARC XML format), there is no limit to the amount of records that can be imported at one time but the code may fail if too many item records are to be created for a single bibliographic record.

section.title: Batch Process Filter Criteria

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch Process Filter Criteria
> Batch Process Filter Criteria Lookup

section.para: The Batch Process Filter Criteria is a maintenance document used to support exporting bibliographic records. Filter Criteria can be selected from the batch process profile to narrow down which records will be exported when the profile is used.

note.para: Batch Process Filter Criteria cannot be edited via the interface. Technical assistance is required to add new or edit existing batch process filter criteria.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Filter Criteria Lookup with Search Results

section.para: As a function of OLE, you may search for batch process filter criteria. Execute a blank search to review the available batch process filter criteria.

section.title: Batch Process Job Details

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch Process Job Details
> Batch Process Job Details

section.para: The Batch Process Job Details screen displays the batch jobs that have run or are currently running. Staff may also restart a job, view the job report and remove the job from OLE from this interface.

If you have run a batch job and the Batch Process Job Details screen opened automatically, only your corresponding job will be displayed. If you open the screen from the OLE menu, all jobs will be displayed.

Enter dates into the Date Create From and/or the Date Created To fields or use the calendar icon
and click Search
to narrow down the results which appear in the Batch Process Job Details table.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Job Details: Sample Output

section.para: Click View Job Report to view the report. If there were files that failed, the Job Report will display a link to the failure reason.
Below is an example of an batch export job report:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Job Details: Sample Job Report

section.para: For batch exports only, clicking the View Export File(s) link allows you to view the files:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Job Details: File List

section.para: If the batch export type is incremental, the next time the job runs it will output a file of new and changed records and a .txt file of bib IDs for deleted bib records. If holdings records are modified or deleted, the bib record is output again in the next incremental update with only the holdings that remain output to the 9xx fields.

section.title: Batch Process Profile

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch Process Profile
> Batch Process Profile Lookup

note.para: Please click here for technical documentation.

section.para: When you select the Batch Process Profile link from the Admin menu, the system displays the Batch Process Profile lookup. This screen allows staff to search for and edit pre-existing Batch Process Profiles or create new profiles.

note.para: Once a Batch Process Profile is created, it cannot be deleted from the user interface.

section.title: Document Layout

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document

section.para: When creating a new Batch Process Profile, the Main Section is standard. Depending on the Batch Process Type that is selected, different tabs are available for adding or modifying information for the profile.

section.title: Main Section tab
section.para: The Main Section tab contains basic information about the Batch Process Profile. Additional fields will appear in the Main Section tab depending on the Batch Process Type that is selected.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Main Section

entry.para: Enter the name of the Batch Process.

Required. Enter the type of batch process or search for it from the lookup
. For example, import patron, export bib, import order.
Display only. Indicates whether the vendor is a parent or child record.
If the Bib Import type is selected, select the data type to import from the drop down list.
If the Order Record Import type is selected, select from the drop down list to have one requisition created per title or one requisition created for the order.

It the Order Record Import type is selected, and the file to be imported contains MARC records with embedded order data, check this box. If importing order data from an EDIFACT file, do not check this box.

If the Order Record Import or Invoice Import type is selected, the Bib Import Profile is required to create or overlay bibliographic records. Search for the Bib Import Profile by the lookup
to govern bib import parameters.
If the Batch Export type is selected, select from the drop down list to have only bibliographic data, bibliographic, holdings and item data, or bibliographic, holdings and e-holdings data exported.
If the Batch Export type is selected, select from the drop down list how much should be exported: full export, filtered, incremental, or full except staff only bibs.

section.para: For Patron import, Location import, Invoice import, Claim Report and Serial Record Import the Main Section is the only tab available for adding or editing information.

Click Submit
to create a new profile for these types of batch processes.

note.para: Serials Record Import was developed specifically for early adopters to migrate data into OLE. The loader allows data migrators to create three tables of data and load them without interfering with the workflow processes required by Rice. The three tables must be formatted in a very specific way. Each implementer, being unique in their previous systems, will have to work to create their own CSV or XML files to import. For additional information about the University of Chicago's experience with the loader for 1.5, see OLE-5642. If you have additional questions, please email ole.technical.usergroup@kuali.org.

section.para: Additional information for all other batch process types will be addressed below.

section.title: Order Record Import or Invoice Import: Constant and Default Values Tab
section.para: OLE supports two ways of importing order data:

listitem.para: from a file of EDIFACT order messages, loaded in conjunction with a file of bibliographic data
from order data embedded in each bibliographic record in a file

section.para: Order Record Import profiles have a "Marc only" checkbox on them. If checked, the profile will expect the user to load a file of bibliographic records alone, and will extract data from it to populate the order record. If the checkbox is left unchecked, it will expect the user to load a pair of files (bibliographic and EDIFACT) when using that profile.

If you are creating orders via embedded order data, you must specify which bibliographic fields and subfields contain which pieces of data. (This will vary from file to file, depending on the coding used by the data creator.) You can specify the mapping from bibliographic data to the requisition using the Constant and Default Values and Data Mapping sections of the profile.
Invoice import can likewise be done two ways:

listitem.para: by loading a file of EDIFACT invoice messages
by loading bibliographic records containing embedded invoice data

section.para: When loading an EDIFACT order message, you do not need to load bibliographic data at the same time. The file will try to match the invoice lines to existing purchase order lines as part of the load.
When loading invoice data embedded in bibliographic data, your invoice import profile should be linked to an existing bib import profile.
If the Order Record Import or Invoice Import type is selected from the Main Section, a new tab will load.

Enter the constant and default values and click Add
.

listitem.para: Constant: The value entered in the profile will override the present value or add a value if one was not present in the incoming invoice file.
Default: The value entered in the profile will be added to the created document if the value is not available in the incoming invoice file.

note.para: Do not forget to select items for the additional Main Section fields.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Constand and Default Values for Order Record Import and Invoice Import

entry.para: Select the Data Type from the drop down menu.
Depending on the Data Type selected, select the field name from the drop down list.
Enter the field name to be defined as the constant or default value.
Enter the field value to be defined as the constant or default value.
Select the radio button for default or constant.

Click Add
to add the Default or Constant value.

section.para:
Once your Order Record Import profile is completed, click Submit
.

section.title: The following fields are mandatory for an Order Record Import profile to create the Requisition.
section.para: For EDI and MARC (Constant and Default Values section):

listitem.para: Default Location

note.para: The default location must come from only one subfield (for example: 980 $x), it cannot be two (980 $x$y).

The default location in your MARC record must match the location exactly as it appears in the Requisition's location dropdown. If three levels are used at your institution and three levels appear on the Requisition, then all three levels must be in you MARC subfield. Additionally, location levels must be separated by slashes ($xUC/DDL/Law).

listitem.para:
Item Type
This Item Type does not refer to the Item Type listed on an Item Record (the maintenance table listed under Cataloging Maintenance). This refers to the line item on PURAP (S&A) documents. The only valid choice is "ITEM".
Item Types in the item record need to be entered on a Bib Import Profile that can be linked to the Order Import Profile.
Cost Source
Method of PO Transmission
Building Code
Delivery Campus Code
Org Code
Chart Code

note.para: A valid Fund Code may be substituted for chart, account, and object codes.

listitem.para: Funding Source

section.para: For MARC only (Constant and Default Values section or Data Mapping section):

listitem.para: List Price
Vendor Number
Quantity
No Of Parts
Account Number
Object Code
Default Location

Item Type
This Item Type does not refer to the Item Type listed on an Item Record (the maintenance table listed under Cataloging Maintenance). This refers to the line item on PURAP (S&A) documents. The only valid choice is "ITEM".
Item Types in the item record need to be entered on a Bib Import Profile that can be linked to the Order Import Profile.
Cost Source
Method of PO Transmission
Building Code
Delivery Campus Code
Org Code
Chart Code

note.para: A valid Fund Code may be substituted for chart, account, and object codes.

listitem.para: Funding Source

section.para: Item Description is required for EDIFACT or MARC files that will not have a matching PO line item. Currently in OLE without a linked PO, or including the Item Description, the batch process will fail with the reason "Error Message:null".

note.para: There is a bug ticket for the Item Description and its error message. See OLE-7057

section.para: When typing a field value into the Constant and Default Values section, you must enter it formatted exactly as it is within OLE. For example, when adding Requestor Name you need to add LastName, FirstName.

section.title: Creating and Linking Items and E-Holdings during Order Record Import with a Bib Import Profile attached
section.para: When running the batch process for order imports, the Bib Import Profile is executed first and then the Order Import Profile.

Items and E-Holdings can be created by the Bib Import Profile and by the Order Record Import via the Requision's transition to a Purchase Order. In order to prevent OLE from creating both, a check has been added to the Order Record Import Profile. If an e-holdings or item record is created or modified by the Bib Import Profile, a second e-holding/item will not be created during the Requisition's transition to a Purchase Order. This ensures that only one new e-holding/item is linked to the Purchase Order and Bibliographic Record.

note.para: OLE cannot run an Order Import batch process with hundreds of items. Additionally, the more items links to each order, the more time the system will take to import the order.

section.title: EDI Invoice Import Match Points
section.para: OLE will try to match each invoice line with its corresponding purchase order line. Match points are:

listitem.para: Primary match - the vendor’s ID number: stored in the Vendor Item Identifier field of the PO line item, and in the SNA segment of the EDIFACT message
Secondary match - ISSN, stored in the bib. record and in the PIA+5 segment of the EDIFACT message
Tertiary match - the OLE PO number, stored in the PO and the RFF+ON segment of the EDIFACT message

section.title: Batch Delete: Match Point Tab
section.para:
If the Batch Delete type is selected from the Main Section, a new tab will load. The Bib Match Point tab is used to determine what records will be deleted from OLE. Enter the match point and click Add
. Users may add as many match points as is necessary.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Match Point Tab for Batch Delete

section.title: Batch Export
section.para: OLE does not provide a public discovery layer. As a result, staff will need to export bibliographic, Holdings, Item, and E-Holdings data to various existing discovery layers. The existing systems expect MARC21 bibliographic records with 9xx local data fields containing a subset of information from Holdings and Item records attached to the bibliographic records. OLE is able to suppress bibliographic or Holdings and Item data marked as staff only. OLE will also dump incremental updates with additions, modifications and deletions to bibliographic or Holdings and Item data as required by each library. OLE also allows the user to specify frequency of full and incremental exports. All of these actions can be set up in the profile and carried out through the Batch Process interface.

If the Batch Export type is selected from the Main Section, four additional tabs will load: Filter Criteria, Data Mapping, Delete Field, and Rename Field.
Do not forget to select items for the additional Main Section fields.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Filter Criteria, Data Mapping, Delete Field, Rename Field Tabs for Batch Export

section.title: Filter Criteria Tab
section.para:
If you chose "filter" in the Export Scope field of the Main Section, the Filter Criteria tab will appear. Enter the filter criteria and click Add
.

note.para: If you are filtering by "Bib Local ID from File", you cannot add any additional filters.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Filter Criteria

entry.para: Select the field name from the drop down list.
If the field name does not appear in the Select Field drop down list, enter the field name to be defined as the constant or default value.
Enter the field value to be defined as the constant or default value.
Enter a beginning field range to limit the filter.
Enter an ending field range to limit the filter.

Click Add
to add the Filter Criteria value.

section.title: Data Mapping Tab
section.para:
Click Add
to add data mapping options.

Data mapping is divided into two sections. The first identifies the source field for the export and the second identities the destination field for which OLE will map to. Enter the source and destination information and click the Add
button next to Priority.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Data Mapping Tab

entry.para: Select the type of data (Holding, Item, EHolding) from the drop down list.
If you have chosen holding or item as the data type, select the OLE source field from the drop down menu.
If you have chosen bibmarc as the data type, enter a source field. For example "100 $a"
If you have chosen bibmarc as the data type, enter a source field value.
Select the type of destination data type (bibmarc, holding or item) from the drop down list.
If you have chosen holding or item as the data type, select the destination field from the drop down menu.
If you have chosen bibmarc as the destination data type, enter a destination field. For example "100 $a"
If you have chosen bibmarc as the data type, enter a destination field value.
If the same source field is given multiple destinations, you may prioritize which should be first, second, third, and so on.

note.para: You cannot map incoming data from multiple fields to a single field in OLE, unless you set priorities. In that case only the first met priority field will be mapped.

entry.para:
Click Add
to add the Data Mapping value.

section.title: Delete Field Tab
section.para:
The Delete Field tab allows you to identify fields that will be deleted during the export. Enter the field information and click Add
. Add as many fields as is needed.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Delete Field Tab

entry.para: Enter the bibliographic field name to be deleted. For example "101" or "245"
Optional. Enter the first indicator to be deleted.
Optional. Enter the second indicator to be deleted.
Optional. Enter the subfield to be deleted.
Optional. Enter the information the subfield contains that will be deleted during the export.

Click Add
to add the Delete Field value.

section.title: Rename Field Tab
section.para:
The Rename Field tab is used to rename or change fields during the export. It is divided into two sections. The first identifies the original tag within OLE for the export and the second identities the newly named field in the exported record. Enter information for both the original and rename tags and click Add
.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Rename Field

entry.para: Enter the numeric MARC tag that you wish to rename.
Enter the Indicator 1 that will be changed.
Enter the Indicator 2 that will be changed.
Enter the subfield that will be changed.
Enter the information that the subfield contains to be changed.
Enter the replacing numeric MARC tag.

Click Add
to add the Rename Field value.

section.title: Example
section.para: The most common set up for a batch export is the "incremental" type (set by Export Scope), without a filter and with data mapping of Holdings data as required by the library's discovery layer.
Here is an example:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document with Sample Data for Batch Export

section.para: After creating and saving your Batch Process Profile, go to the Batch Process interface to set up your incremental export to run on a schedule.

section.title: Batch Export: Bib Local ID from File
section.para: Set up the Profile:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile for exporting by Bib Local ID from File

listitem.para: In the Document Overview: Enter a Description
In the Main Section: Enter a Batch Profile Name, search for the Batch Process Type “Batch Export”, select a type of Data to Export, and select the Export Scope “Filter”.
In the Filter Criteria: Select “Bib Local ID from File” under Select Field Name. Click Add.

note.para: You cannot filter on any additional filters for this type of export.

listitem.para: Click Submit

section.para: From the Batch Process:

listitem.para:
Select the Batch Process Profile Name from the Lookup
.
In the Input Section: Click Browse… to search your computer for the .txt file

important.para: This .txt file’s local identifiers must be separated by a line break

listitem.para: Click Submit
When the Batch Process Job Details screen appears, refresh your screen to see the completed job. Click View Job Report to download the exported file.

section.title: Batch Export: Filtering by Location

note.para: Unless the location data happens to be mimicked in your bibliographic records there is not a great way to do this yet. Jira ticket OLE-7086 calls for the ability to batch export on values in the holdings and item record.

section.para: Here are some possible workarounds used by some partners:

listitem.para: Peform an SQL query to retrieve locations and Bib IDs. Load the created Bib ID file using a Batch Export Profile created to Filter by "Bib Local ID from File", see Batch Export: Bib Local ID from File.
Perform your search in Search Workbench until you get the results that you would like.

note.para: For more information about the Search Workbench, Search Workbench under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para: Check every box next to the titles, then click "Export to DocXML".

From here, you can either a) open this in notepad and extract the BibID tags, then dedup (The Export to DocXML gives three records for each title) or b) you can use MARCEdit to convert MARCXML to MARC and extract the bib ids that way.

Use that .txt file to do a Batch Export in OLE using a Batch Export Profile created to Fileter by "Bib Local ID from File". Do not try to use the records you retrieve from Export to DocXML because they are messy. You need a fresh file once you have identified the Bib IDs.

section.title: Bib Import
section.para: For a demonstration of several Bib Imports in OLE 1.5.2.1, watch "Bib Import 101" available under OLE Demonstration Library - OLE 1.5 Demos. The demonstration presents the setup of several different bib import profiles and the batch processing of .mrc files to import records using the created profiles into OLE. Additionally, to see the step-by-step functionality of the Bib Import profile, see the Google Document: Spec - Batch Import

note.para: You will need to log into KIS to view this document.

section.para: If the Bib Import type is selected from the Main Section, additional tabs will load: Match Point, Matching, Add and Overlay Section, Set Bib Status, Staff Only Treatment, Changes to Imported Bibliographic Record, Constant and Default Values (described above), Data Mapping, Protected Field, Delete Field, and Rename Field.

note.para: All imported MARC bibliographic records must be Unicode-compliant (UTF-8).

section.para: In the Main Section, be sure to select the Data to Import that is relevant for your import files. If you select "Bibliographic, Holdings, Item and EHoldings" but only import E-Holdings records, you will end up with extraneous holdings and items. Additionally, the Constant and Default Values should match the data to import. If you create a profile and select "Bibliographic and EHoldings Data", do not enter any constant or default values for Holdings and Items - only for E-Holdings.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Match Point, Matching, Add and Overlay Section, Set Bib Status, Staff Only Treatment, Changes to Imported Bibliographic Record, Constant and Default Value, Data Mapping, Protected Field, Delete Field, Rename Field Tabs for Bib Import

section.title: Match Point Tab
section.para:
On the Match Point tab, you may enter match point(s) for the bibliographic, holding, item, or e-holding records. If you add more than one match point, OLE will prioritize them by the order they have been entered (First entered, first matched). Click Add
after adding each match point.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Match Point Tab

section.title: Matching, Add and Overlay Section
section.para: Depending on the Data to Import selection you have chosen on the Main Section Tab, the Matching, Add and Overlay Section allows user to determine what the course of action will be when importing records. Click the radio buttons to make your selection.

tip.para: Follow the tree structure to make your selections - decide: Do not perform matching on incoming Bib with existing Bibs or Perform matching of incoming Bib with existing Bibs. If you choose to perform matching, look at the next set up of If statements and make your selections. Continue on only as deeply into the tree structure as you need to go.
Only open one section at a time, as needed (focus on bibs first, then look at Process Holdings and Items).
One radio buttons will always be selected in each section, even when that section is not applicable.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Matching, Add and Overlay Section

tip.para: The Process Holdings and Items section does not mention e-holdings. When loading records that will have e-holdings, the term “holdings” can be applied to holdings and e-holdings. Process Items does not apply at all to e-holdings.

note.para: Matching and overlaying on existing records with multiple e-holdings is currently not working (see OLE-7700).

section.title: Set Bib Status Tab
section.para: Depending on the Data to Import selection you have chosen on the Main Section Tab, the Set Bib Status tab allows user to set the statuses of the new or overlaid bibliographic records. Select the statuses from the drop down menu. For overlaid records, you may choose not to change the status.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Set Bib Status Tab

section.title: Staff Only Treatment Tab
section.para: The Staff Only Treatment tab allows user to turn on the staff only flag in the cataloging record. For new records, check the box to apply the staff only flag to new bibliographic, Holdings, or Item records. To set staff only for overlaid bibs, check the box at For Overlaid Bib set Staff Only.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Staff Only Treatment

section.title: Changes to Imported Bibliographic Record Tab
section.para: The Changes to Imported Bibliographic Record tab allows users to modify or delete the 001 field if one exists in the incoming record. If you choose to replace the 001 with a new 035, you will be asked about prepending the contents of the 001 with the 003 field in parenthesis or with a stated value (the prepended contents of the 003 field then the 001 field will appear on a new 035 field in the imported record). To remove prefixes from the incoming 001 data, check the box by Remove from 001 and enter the prefix to remove, for example, ocn or ocn, ocm.

tip.para: If you are matching bibliographic records on the 035 $a, the incoming records need to have data already in the 035 $a. If that data only exists in the 001/003, it will not match existing records and new record will be added, even though the 001/003 will be combined to create a new 035 $a. This is because actions during the batch process occur in the order listed in the profile, so the process FIRST looks for a match on the 035 $a, and then switches out data from the 001/003 to a new 035.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Changes to Imported Bibliographic Record Tab

section.title: Constant and Default Values
section.para: The Constant and Default Values tab is used to set default or constant values in OLE bibliographic, holding, e-holding, and item fields.

When setting Constant and Default values for e-holdings, you can select the E-Resource Name and Platform from drop down menus in the profile. This will create links between the newly created e-holdings and the E-Resource and Platform records, respectively.
In order to have the e-holdings be “active,” be sure to select Access Status from the dropdown menu for e-holdings and then select the value “active.”

Enter the constant or default values and click Add
.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Constant and Default Values

entry.para: Select the type of date (bib, holding or item) from the drop down list.
If you selected holding or item from the Data Type, select the field name from the drop down list.
Enter the field name to be defined as the constant or default value.
Enter the field value to be defined as the constant or default value.
Select the radio button for default or constant.

listitem.para: “Constant” data will be added to all records created or modified by the batch process.
“Default” data will be added to records if there is nothing found on the incoming record. Data will be added unless other data is identified for that field in the Data Mapping section.

entry.para:
Click Add
to add the Default or Constant value.

section.title: Data Mapping Tab
section.para:
Click Add
to add data mapping options.

The Data mapping tab is divided into two sections. The first identifies the source field for the import and the second identities the destination field for OLE. Enter the source and destination information and click the Add
button next to Priority.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Data Mapping Tab

entry.para: Select the type of data (bibmarc, holding or item) from the drop down list.
If you have chosen holding or item as the data type, select the OLE source field from the drop down menu.
If you have chosen bibmarc as the data type, enter a source field. For example "100 $a"
If you have chosen bibmarc as the data type, enter a source field value.
Select the type of destination data type (bibmarc, holding or item) from the drop down list.
If you have chosen holding or item as the data type, select the destination field from the drop down menu.

note.para: The Destination Field options do not appear until you have made a selection in the Destination Data Type Field.

tip.para: If you choose a location level from the dropdown for Holdings or Items, be sure that your institution has a location assigned to that level.

entry.para: If you have chosen bibmarc as the destination data type, enter a destination field. For example "100 $a"
If you have chosen bibmarc as the data type, enter a destination field value to overlay or add the value to the newly created record. Leave blank for the incoming record to populate the field.

note.para: The values in this field are not applicable to holdings and item records. The batch process will ignore any data you enter in this field for these record types.

entry.para: If the same incoming record could have the same information in multiple fields (for example call numbers), you may prioritize which should fill the OLE record first or second, and so on.

note.para: You cannot map incoming data from multiple fields to a single field in OLE, unless you set priorities. In that case only the first met priority field will be mapped.

entry.para:
Click Add
to add the Delete Field value.

note.para: If your Bib Import Profile is set to create holdings and items, then you will need to specify a data source for the two required fields in the item record: Item Status and Item Type. These can be specified either in the Constant and Default Data section or the Data Mapping section.

section.title: Special Consideration for E-Holdings
section.para: When loading e-holdings, you must map a source field (e.g., 856 $u) to the URL Destination Field in the e-holdings in order for any e-holdings to be created. The existence of this mapping is what triggers the e-holdings’ creation. If your incoming record has repeated source fields that are mapped to the URL Destination Field, each URL will trigger the creation of a new e-holdings.

listitem.para: Data located within the same field as the URL will be mapped specifically with that URL to an e-holdings. For example, if you map 856 $u to URL and 856 $y to Link Text, each 856 in the bib record will create a new e-holdings, with unique values for the URL and Link Text field.

Data located outside of the same field as the URL will be mapped only once to all created e-holdings. For example, if you map the 856 $u to URL and the 050 $a$b to Call Number, each 856 in the bib records will create a new e-holdings, with unique values for the URL, but the same value for the Call Number, coming from the first instance of the 050 $a$b

Mapping to the E-Resource Name and Platform will create links to those different records, respectively. If the E-Resource Name and Platform are different for each e-holdings created, place that information into the same source field as the URL (e.g., if the 956 $u is mapped to URL, you could map the E-Resource Name from the 956 $a and the Platform from the 956 $b). Otherwise, the same E-Resource Name and Platform will be applied to all e-holdings created.

If you map to the E-Resource Name and Platform but the incoming data does not match any existing E-Resource Records or Platforms, the e-holdings will still be created, but the link to the E-Resource Record or Platform will not be created. An error will be reported in the Batch Process Job Details.

note.para: For more information about Batch Process Job Details, see Batch Process Job Details.

section.title: Protected Fields Tab
section.para:
The Protected Fields tab is divided into two tabs.
The Globally Protected Fields allows user to view the globally protected fields defined for your OLE system. Click the checkbox to ignore the global protection of any of the fields listed.
For information on how to add and maintain globally protected fields, see the section under the Describe and Manage Module.
The Profile Protected Fields allows users to add fields to protect only when using this profile. Input field information and click Add
.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Protected Field Tab

section.title: Delete Field
section.para:
The Delete Field tab allows you to identify entire fields to be deleted from the imported record(s) during the import process. Enter the field information and click Add
. Add as many fields as is needed.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Delete Field Tab

entry.para: Enter the bibliographic numeric tag of the field to be deleted. For example "710" or "245"

row.entry: Optional. Use to delete a field with a particular first indicator value. Example: To delete field 510 with first indicator 4, enter "510" as Field Name and "4" as First Indicator.

entry.para: Optional. Use to delete a field with a particular second indicator value. Example: To delete field 856 with second indicator 1, enter "856" as Field Name, and "1" as Second Indicator.
Optional. Use to delete a particular subfield within a field. Example: To delete subfield 2 from field 655, enter "655" in Field Name and "2" in Subfield.

Optional. Use to delete a field when it contains a subfield with a particular value. Example: To delete field 710 when subfield a contains LINK, enter "710" in Field Name, "a" in Subfield, and "LINK" in Subfield Contains.

Click Add
to add the Delete Field value.

section.title: Rename Field
section.para:
The Rename Field tab is used to change field tags and data during the import. It is divided into two sections. The first identifies the original tag from the imported record and the second identities the newly named MARC elements in the OLE record. Enter information for both the original and renamed data and click Add
.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Rename Field Tab

entry.para: Enter the numeric tag from the imported record that you wish to rename during import.
Enter the value of Indicator 1 from the imported record that will be changed.
Enter the value of Indicator 2 from the imported record that will be changed.
Enter the subfield from the imported record that will be changed.
Enter the information that the subfield contains that will be changed.
Enter the information that will replace the content in the imported record.

Click Add
to add the Rename Field value.

section.title: Examples
section.para: Rename tag 546 to 500:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Rename Field with Original Tag 546, Rename Tag 500

section.para: Change 245 first indicator value from 0 to 1:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Rename Field with Original Tag 245, Ind 1 set to 0, Rename Tag 245, Ind 1 set to 1

section.para: Change 730 second indicator value from 2 to 0:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Rename Field with Original Tag 730, Ind 2 set to 2, Rename Tag 740, Ind 2 set to 0

section.para: Change 651 subfield x to 651 subfield v:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Rename Field with Original Tag 651, Subfield set to x, Rename Tag 651, Subfield set to v

section.para: Change 650 subfield z with text "Siam" to "Thailand":

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Rename Field with Original Tag 650, Subfield set to z, containing Siam, Rename Tag 650, Subfield set to z, containing Thailand

section.title: Bib Import with multiple holdings and multiple items
section.para: To import multiple holdings and items with the Bib Import Profile, you will need to enter information for at least two different destination fields: A "Location Level5" for both the holdings, and a "Holdings Location Level5" for the item. (Depending on your institution, you may need to include additional location levels.) If you do not include these location level destination fields, the bib import profile will only create one holding and one item per bibliographic record. For Example:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Data Mapping tab with the three location fields required for multiple holdings and items

warning.para: Leave the Destination Field Value blank. The created records will not include the values if you enter them in this field.

section.title: GOKb Import
section.para: GOKb import uses set parameters when bringing in TIPPs from GOKb or updating existing e-holdings and bibliographic records through a GOKb update. The profile allows you to control how fields are brought into the bibliographic and e-holdings records. Data from GOKb that links to e-resource, vendor, and platform records is not controlled through this import profile, but is hardcoded in the system.
Many of the sections for the GOKb import are the same as for the Bibliographic import, but there are some differences, as described below.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Profile Document: Match Point, Matching, Add and Overlay Section, Set Bib Status, Staff Only Treatment, Changes to Imported Bibliographic Record, Constant and Default Value, Bib Data Mapping, Bib Data Mapping Overlay, Data Mapping, Protected Field, Delete Field, Rename Field Tabs for GOKb Import

section.title: Batch Process Schedule

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch Process Schedule
> Batch Process Schedule

section.para: The Batch Process Schedule displays jobs that are scheduled to run. Staff may also reschedule or remove the job from OLE.

section.title: Batch Process Type

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> Batch Process Type
> Batch Process Type Lookup

section.para: The Batch Process Type is a maintenance document used to support batch process profile. Depending on the batch process type selected, the Batch Process Profile will display particular tabs and fields. Batch Process Types are heavily tied into the workflow of batch processes and therefore you cannot add or edit Batch Process Types.

note.para: Technical assistance is required to add new or edit existing batch process types.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Process Type Lookup with Search Results

section.para: As a function of OLE, you may search for batch process types. Execute a blank search to review the available batch process types.

section.title:
Batch File Batch File Lookup
System submenu group, Batch menu Batch File Lookup

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> OLE FS Batch
> Batch File
> Batch File Lookup

section.para: The Batch File lookup allows users to view OLE files, reports and logs. Users can search for files by name, date and by indicating what OLE file directory they reside in. Batch files can be downloaded or deleted.
Only members of OLE-SYS Manager group can download and act on batch files through this interface.

mediaobject.alt: Batch File Lookup Display

entry.para: Select the directory or sub-directory in which the file you wish to retrieve resides. Click the directory you wish to search.

In the default configuration the 'reports' directory contains reports and log files generated by batch jobs. These reports exist in sub-directories corresponding to the module that owns the batch job.

The Staging directory contains input files brought into OLE (such as procurement card or collector upload files) as well as export files generated by OLE (such as check files from PDP). These reports also exist in sub-directories corresponding to the module they are associated with.
Some modules may have additional sub-directories further dividing their Staging output.
Enter the file you wish to retrieve.
Enter or use the calendar to select a beginning date range for your search.
Enter or use the calendar to select an ending date range for your search.

section.para: Reports that match your search will be displayed, showing their name, location and file size (in bytes.) Options in the Actions column allow you to Download or Delete the files.

mediaobject.alt: Batch File: Sample Reports

warning.para: Note that manually deleting files via this interface should be done with great caution. There is no interface to undo a deletion and removing certain files may cause batch jobs or processes to fail.

section.para: The most common use for deleting a file is to remove a '.done' file from data files such as those created by the GLCP, LLCP or uploaded via the Collector. OLE creates two files for these particular processes, one ending in a '.data' extension and another ending in a '.done' extension. Deleting the '.done' extension file will keep the associated '.data' file from being processed by its associated batch processes but leave the data file itself for reference.

section.title: Batch/Scheduled Jobs

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> OLE FS Batch
> Batch/Schedule Jobs
> Batch Job Lookup
> Batch Job

note.para: Please click here for technical documentation.

section.para: The Batch/Scheduled Jobs document allows users to edit the cron expression that specifies when the particular job should be scheduled. This interface is only for OLE-created jobs (Circulation jobs for example) and not KFS-inherited jobs. To learn more about each of the jobs available in Deliver, see batch processes under the Deliver Module.

section.title: Batch Job Lookup
section.para: You cannot create a new document. You must search for a job and choose to edit it from the search results.

tip.para: Enter a blank search to see all available jobs and their cron expressions. From the results, select the job you would like to edit.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Lookup Screen

section.title: Document Layout

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document

section.para: This screen includes unique Add/Edit Batch Job and Run/Schedule Batch Job tabs in addition to the standard tabs that display on OLE document screens.

note.para: For more information about the standard tabs, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

section.title: Add/Edit Batch Job

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Add/Edit Batch Job tab

section.para: The Batch Job document includes the Add/Edit Batch Job tab. The system automatically enters data into both the Old and New sections in this tab.

entry.para: Display Only. The name of the batch job that needs to be scheduled.
Display Only. The cron expression for when the job is scheduled to run.
Check the box to allow the job to run.

section.title: Run/Schedule Batch Job

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job tab

section.para: The Batch Job document includes the Run/Schedule Batch Job tab.
Click Run Now and Submit to start the job. Click Schedule to choose a date and time to start the job. Choosing Schedule opens a new tab:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job: Schedule tab

section.para: You have two options to schedule your batch job.

listitem.para: Click Provide Cron Expression and enter the Cron Expression. See Job CRON Expression - controlling the frequency/schedule of job execution below for assistance entering the Expression

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job: Schedule tab to enter CRON Expressions

listitem.para: Click Schedule to enter a specified date or recurring dates for the batch job to run.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job: Schedule tab to enter a scheduled time or recurring time

listitem.para: You may also choose the radio button Schedule to manually enter when the job should occur. You will have two options:

One Time: Enter the date or search for it from the calendar icon
and time for the job to begin.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job: Schedule Tab set to schedule a one time job

listitem.para: Recurring: Select the schedule type Daily, Weekly or Monthly.
If you selected the Schedule Type Daily, enter the time for the job to begin.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job: Schedule Tab set to schedule a daily recurring job

listitem.para: If you selected the Schedule Type Weekly, enter the time for the job to begin and check the box for the days of the week that the job should run.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job: Schedule Tab set to schedule a weekly recurring job

listitem.para: If you selected the Schedule Type Monthly, enter the time for the job to begin, select the calendar date (for example, 23 for the 23rd day of each month), and enter the number of months that should elapse before the job runs again (for example, you may set the job to run every 3 or 6 months).

inlinemediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Run/Schedule Batch Job: : Schedule Tab set to schedule a monthly recurring job

section.para:
Once your schedule has been determined, click Submit
.

section.title: Pick up Location (for On Hold Notices)
section.para: If you have selected the generateOnHoldNoticeJob, an additional tab will be available. Pick up Location allows you to regulate the printing or electronic transmission of Deliver notices for the entire system by Circulation Location/Library Name if desired. If left blank, the job will run for all locations.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Document: Picku up Location

section.para: Select the Pick-up Location from the drop down list. The list will only include locations for which you are authorized.

note.para:
GenerateOnHoldNoticeJob is the main hold notice job for all pick-up locations. Changing it’s values to one pick up location or by selecting the Run Now
value will stop all other hold notices from running. To run an on demand hold notice job for one pick up location, separate from or in addition to the regularly scheduled generateOnHoldNoticeJob, use the Circulation Desk Inquiry.

section.title: Circulation Desk Inquiry
section.para:
Maintenance
> Circulation Admin
> Circulation Desk
> Circulation Desk Lookup
> Circulation Desk

The Circulation Desk Lookup allows staff to view circulation desks and the Inquiry allows staff to run hold notices notice jobs for circulation desks that have already been mapped. By clicking the Generate On Hold Notice
button, staff can initiate an on demand, one time hold notice job that runs independantly of generateOnHoldNoticeJob.

mediaobject.alt: Circulation Desk Inquiry includes a Generate On Hold Notice button

section.title: Job CRON Expression - controlling the frequency/schedule of job execution

note.para: OLE uses the Quartz Job Scheduler as its authority on Cron expressions.

section.para: CRON enables users to schedule jobs to run periodically at certain times or dates. A CRON expression is a string comprised of 5 or 6 fields separated by white space that represents a set of times, normally as a schedule to execute some routine.

entry.para: Represents seconds. The allowed values are 0-59.
2 0 12 * * ? - This will fire the job at 12:00:02 PM every day.
0/2 0 12 * * ? - This will fire the job every 2 seconds from 12:00:00 PM to 12:00:58 PM every day.
Represents minutes. The allowed values are 0-59.
0 5 12 * * ? - This will fire the job at 12:05 PM every day.
0 0/5 12 * * ? - This will fire the job every 5 minutes from 12:00 PM to 12:55 PM every day.
Represents hours. The allowed values are 0-23.
0 5 10 12 * * ? - This will fire the job at 12:05 PM every day.
0 5 12,18 * * ? - This will fire the job every 5 minutes from 12:00 PM to 12:55 PM and from 6:00 PM to 6:55 PM every day.
Represents days of the month. The allowed values are 1-31.
0 5 10 12 * * - This will fire the job at 10:05 AM on the 12th day of every month.
0 0 12 1/5 * ? - This will fire the job at 12:00 PM every 5 days every month, starting on the first day of the month.
Represents months. The allowed values are 1-12 or JAN-DEC.
0 11 11 11 11 ? or 0 11 11 11 NOV ? - This will fire the job at 11:11 AM on November 11th of each year.
Represents days of the week. The allowed values are 1-7 or SUN-SAT.
0 10,44 14 ? 3 WED or 0 10,44 14 ? 3 4 - This will fire the job at 2:10 PM and 2:44 PM on every Wednesday in the month of March.
0 10,44 14 ? 3 WED-FRI - This will fire the job at 2:10 PM and 2:44 PM from Wednesday to Friday each week during the month of March.
0 0 12 * * ? - This will fire the job at 12:00 PM every day of every month in each year.
Represents no specific value for the particular field.
0 0 12 * * ? - This will fire the job at 12:00 PM every day of every month in each year irrespective of the day in a week.
Represents the range of values for a corresponding field.
0 0 14 ? * WED-FRI - This will fire the job at 2:00 PM from Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of every week.
Represents incremental values specified to the field
0 0 0/2 * * ? - This will fire the job every 2 hours starting at 12 AM.
Represents the last value in the specified field. This character is only allowed in the fourth and sixth field.
0 15 10 ? * 6L - This will fire the job at 10:15 AM on the last Friday of every month.
0 15 10 L * ? - This will fire the job at 10:15 AM on the last day of every month.
Represents the "nth" XXX day of the month. This character is only allowed in the sixth field.
0 15 10 ? * 6#3 - This will fire the job at 10:15 AM on the third Friday of every month.
0 15 10 ? * 4#5 - This will fire the job at 10:15 AM on the fifth Wednesday of every month. Note that if there is not a fifth Wednesday, the job will not fire.

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> OLE FS Batch
> Batch Semaphore File Upload
> Batch Error Semaphore File Upload

tip.para: Because this functionality was inherited from KFS, additional information can be found in their technical documentation located on the wiki pages Batch 5 and Batch Container 5.

listitem.para: Currently configured to only upload error files, but can easily be configured to upload the other file types

To upload an error file for a Step (a stage in a job) create a new text file and name it whatever you like. The first line of the file should contain the name of the job and the the name of the Step (the bean id) in the format jobName~stepName. This line and all subsequent lines in the file will be considered error messages and will be logged by BatchStepTrigger.
The File Identifier is required by the upload page, but is not used so enter anything.
Once the file is saved to the batch container directory its name will be jobName~stepName.error.

note.para: In KFS, the Bath Semaphore File Upload is secured by the KFS-SYS Technical Administrator role. While OLE does have a complementary role, the permission "Upload semaphoreInputFileTypeError" will need to be added to the role before using the document.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Error Semaphore File Upload Screen

section.title:
Schedule Schedule option, System submenu group (Batch menu)
System submenu group, Batch menu Schedule option
Batch Job Lookup
Modify Batch Job screen
batch job, modify

para.emphasis:
Admin
> Batch Processes
> OLE FS Batch
> Schedule
> Batch Job Lookup
> Modify Batch Job

note.para: Please click here for technical documentation.

section.para: The Schedule option allows users to view, schedule or execute OLE batch processes (commonly called 'jobs' or 'batch jobs'). Scheduling is very necessary for OLE as there are many jobs - some running nightly, hourly, and others that only run after another job has successfully run.

tip.para: Because this functionality was inherited from KFS, additional information can be found in their technical documentation located on the wiki page Batch 5.

section.para: Only members of OLE-SYS Operations or KR-SYS Technical Administrator role modify batch jobs though this interface though all users can use the batch job lookup. Members of OLE-SYS Operations can edit any existing schedule job belonging to an OLE namespace. Members of KR-SYS Technical Administrators can edit any existing schedule job belonging to the KR namespace.
When you select the Schedule option from the Admin menu, the system displays the Batch Job Lookup. This screen allows you to search for batch jobs by namespace, name, group, and statuses.

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Lookup Screen

entry.para: Select the Namespace (application and module) the job is associated with.
Enter the name of the job prescribed by the system.

Select from the Job Group list. The valid selections are Scheduled: Jobs which are on the standard schedule. Jobs in this group are automatically executed by the schedulerJob. Unscheduled: Normal groups, all jobs are present in this group. These jobs must be executed manually.
Select from the Job Status list. The valid selections are:

Scheduled: Job has been scheduled for later execution Succeeded: Job finished executing successfully Canceled: Job was canceled, either before or during execution Running: Job is currently executing Failed: Job failed during execution
For more detail about the status of a job or any problems it encountered while executing you can view its associated log file using the Batch File Lookup.

section.para: The screen returns the applicable list of jobs:

mediaobject.alt: Batch Job Lookup Search Results

section.para: Every OLE batch job exists in an "unscheduled" version which can be initiated manually at any time. Therefore when you look at the search results for each scheduled job, there are two results shown: one result is in the job group scheduled, and one result is in the job group unscheduled.
There are two ways to initiate a batch job: "running" and "scheduling"

Running: You can either Run a job immediately, or at a specified date/time. If you add a time and click "run", no second job is created; the job remains in the "unscheduled" Job Group although the Job Status changes to "Scheduled".

note.para: For information about how to run a job, see the Running Section below.

section.para: Scheduling: Clicking "schedule" (under Other Commands) instead of "run" adds a second version of the job in the batch job lookup, in the Scheduled job group. You don't specify a date/time for a scheduled job (if you type one in and then click "schedule", OLE just ignores the date/time.) Instead, the timing is controlled by a specific job called "scheduleJob". Its function is to run all the other jobs in the Scheduled job group. It reads the dependencies listed for each job it runs, so it can run them in the right order.

There is a parameter, OLE-SYS CUTOFF_TIME, which controls when the daily batch schedule should terminate. If schedulejob does not complete and some of the dependent jobs are stuck at "Pending", a cut-off time check, which prevents the job from overrunning, is causing the error. Adjust the time on the parameter to correct the problem.

note.para: OLE comes with a cron job that controls the running of the job "scheduleJob". The cron job is not accessible through the UI, however it is accessible through the server. The default setting is to run the jobs daily, at 11:00 PM. You could modify the cron job to run multiple times per day but this has not been tested and it may affect system performance. Instead, if there are particular jobs you wish to run (such as to update the GL immediately), you could run these jobs ad hoc.

section.para: Click the Modify link to open the Modify Batch Job maintenance e-doc.

section.title:
Document Layout batch job, modify
Modify Batch Job screen
batch jobs controlling
section.para: From the Modify Batch Job e-doc, you can run the standard scheduler.

mediaobject.alt: Modify Batch Job Interface

note.para: When the server is restarted, the Job Info values revert back to the original setting unless the configuration is changed.

section.para: This e-doc contains the Job Info tab, the Steps tab, and the Dependencies tab.

section.title: Job Info Tab Modify Batch Job screen Job Info tab
section.para: The Job Info tab displays the basic information about the job and allows you to schedule or unscheduled the job. The Job Infotab includes three sections: Job Info, Running, and Other Commands.

section.title: Job Info Section
section.para: In addition to listing the basic information about the job, clicking the Batch File Lookup URL takes you to the Batch File Lookup screen where you may view logs and reports generated by batch jobs.

mediaobject.alt: Modify Batch Job Interface: Batch File Lookup

note.para: To learn more about the Batch File Lookup screen, see Batch File

section.title: Running Section batch job, scheduling a
section.para: The Running section allows a user to control a job schedule. When the user has appropriate access, the Running section displays information necessary to schedule a job.
By default, when clicking the run button, the system runs all steps of the job immediately or you may schedule the job to start at the specified date and time.

note.para: These parameters can be modified to only run a subset of steps on a job (shown in the Steps tab).

warning.para: When manually running a job, job dependencies are not considered. Caution should be exercised that all necessary data that are normally added by the prerequisite jobs are set up to ensure a successful job run.

mediaobject.alt: Modify Batch Job Interface: Running Section

section.para: If you want to receive an email after the job completes, fill in the email address field or click the Mail to Me button to populate the email address from your user profile into the field. Otherwise, an email will be sent only on job failure, and it will be sent to the batch mailing list.

section.title: Other Commands Section
section.para: You may issue the following commands from this section:

listitem.para:
Click Unschedule
to remove the job from the scheduled group. Clicking 'Unschedule' will remove the job from the scheduled group even if you are viewing an unscheduled version of the job when you click it.
If a job is currently running, you can request that it be interrupted. This does not guarantee an immediate stop.

section.title: Steps Tab Modify Batch Job screen Steps tab
section.para: The Steps tab displays all the steps that make up this batch job. Steps are displayed in the order they are performed.

mediaobject.alt: Modify Batch Job Interface: Steps Tab

section.title: Dependencies Tab Modify Batch Job screen Dependencies tab
section.para: The Dependencies tab displays all the other jobs on which the scheduled version of the current job depends. Batch jobs can have hard or soft dependencies. A soft dependency means that this job will not run until that dependent job has completed, but will run regardless of whether or not the job it depends on completed successfully. A hard dependency indicates that the job must not only complete before this job runs but it must complete successfully.
Note that you can run an unscheduled job without regard to the specified dependencies. The job will run automatically when the run button is clicked.

mediaobject.alt: Modify Batch Job Interface: Dependencies Tab
