section.title: Identity Administration Documents
section.para: The Identity submenu group provides access to screens in order to establish and maintain user data and the associated roles and permissions in the Kuali Identity Management (KIM) system. This system handles user identification, permissions, and responsibilities for multiple Kuali applications, including OLE. KIM may also be used with non-Kuali applications.

OLE communicates with KIM to determine each user's permissions and workflow responsibilities. These permissions and responsibilities are defined by the user's role or roles in the system. Roles can be customized to handle permissions and responsibilities in a variety of ways based on your institution's needs.

note.para: Learn more about KIM functions in the video KIM functions (roles, permissions, responsibilities).

section.title: Menu Access to KIM Functions
section.para: In OLE, most KIM documents are available from the Admin menu tab in the Identity menu group, there are also maintenance documents for these items available from the Maintenance menu. Additionally, the Routing & Identity Management Document Type Hierarchy is available in the Configuration menu group in the Workflow submenu group. The Routing & Identity Management Document Type Hierarchy is a special view that combines KIM data with OLE Document Type Hierarchy. This tool is helpful to see what permissions and responsibilities are assigned to a particular document and can also find the routing sequence of the document.

section.title:
Basic KIM Concepts Kuali Identity Management (KIM)
Kuali Identity Management (KIM) basic concepts
section.para: OLE uses Kuali Identity Management (KIM), software designed to handle permissions and users in a unified way across all Kuali applications. This is particularly important for schools that will ultimately be implementing two or more Kuali systems. KIM is a part of Kuali RICE, underpinning software that all Kuali applications use.
Kuali applications will communicate with KIM to determine what permissions a user has. KIM will also define workflow responsibilities.
In OLE, you do not assign permissions directly to staff. Instead, permissions and responsibilities are assigned to roles. People, or groups of people, are attached to the role.

Your institution may choose to assign permissions and responsibilities differently or even create its own roles to fit business processes. It is important to note that because OLE is built upon KFS and Rice, we have inherited roles from each. Your institution will need to decide what person or group should be assigned to these inherited roles.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Permissions, Responsibilities, Assignees are applied to Roles

section.title: KIM Permissions, Responsibilities, and Roles, and other important concepts
section.para: Some important KIM concepts are defined below.

Permissions: These are the actions OLE needs to authorize users to perform. This might be anything that OLE or other Kuali applications restrict, such as who can initiate a certain type of document, who can maintain referenced data in the application, or who can change the account number on an enroute financial document. Permissions are associated with a Role.

Responsibilities: These are workflow-related actions OLE needs roles to perform. These can be approvals, acknowledgements, or FYI reviews. When a Fiscal Officer approves a financial processing document or a Chart Manager approves a Chart of Accounts maintenance document, the user is acting on a request that has been generated by a responsibility specified in KIM. A role can have any number of responsibilities (including none) associated with it.
Person: The identified individual who needs to be authorized to take some action. A Person in KIM can be assigned one or more Roles.

Roles: Roles combine permissions and responsibilities. Roles can be assigned to Persons or Groups. So instead of “Persons” being assigned permissions directly, the permissions are assigned to Roles and the roles are then assigned to Persons. It’s not uncommon for a Role to be associated with more than one permission or responsibility.

As an example, the Fiscal Officer role includes permission to edit accounting lines on certain en route documents. This role also includes responsibilities that generate requests for the specific actions fiscal officers must take on documents. The Limited Circulation Attendant role includes permissions to view but not make changes to a patron record.

Derived Role: A “Derived Role” is a type of role. Derived roles determine the assignees for the role based on information outside of KIM. Derived roles automatically determine their members from data in other OLE components. OLE has four derived roles currently, all of which were inherited from KFS (see table below). One example, Fiscal Office, is a derived role and determines the assignees for the role based on the Fiscal Officer identified on an Account. You do not need to assign users to derived roles.

Group: Groups provide another important tool in KIM; they are simply a way to associate multiple persons with a role. Groups don’t have any special inherent permission. Groups are an optional feature that allows you to associate persons, roles or other groups with each other for the purpose of making role assignments. For example, if you want to assign the same role to three users, you could create a group, assign the three users to it, and then assign the group to the desired role. (Alternatively, you could add the three users individually to the role. The choice of whether to use a group or assign individual users to roles is entirely yours.)

Namespace: Roles are organized into namespaces, this helps in determining if the role is inherited and also what module it can be used in. A Namespace will also structurally organize, or scope, Permissions and Entity Attributes (people). Each Namespace instance is one level of scoping and is one record in the system. For example, "KR" or "OLE" or "KFS" could be a Namespace. In OLE, we have further broken those up into finer-grained Namespaces such that they would roughly correlate to library departments and functional modules. Examples you will see are "KR-WKFLW" (Kuali Workflow), "OLE-CAT" (OLE Cataloging), and “OLE-PURAP" (OLE Purchasing and Accounts Payable). Roles are required to have namespaces; therefore you will see several roles that share the same name.

Routing & Identity Management Document Type Hierarchy: The Routing & Identity Management Document Type Hierarchy is a unique tool to KIM. This tool allows you to view KIM permissions and responsibilities as they relate to specific OLE documents.

section.title: Users in OLE
section.para: Users of OLE, library staff, are identified on the KIM Person document. The Person document is found on the Admin tab. This document identifies the person by a Principal ID and assigns that person to any number of roles.
The initial ingestion of multiple users is covered within the OLE Implementation Guide on the wiki.
To add a single user to OLE, see Person.

section.title: Permissions for Maintenance Documents
section.para: Permissions for Maintenance documents, those found on the Maintenance Menu, could have the same permissions that are assigned to roles and attached to persons. Typically, however, because Maintenance documents control tables, only persons with the administrative roles may initiate the documents.

There are several exceptions to this. A few maintenance documents, such as for Chart of Accounts, can be initiated and edited by additional roles such as several OLE-SELECT Financial and OLE-SELECT Accounting roles. These maintenance documents will route.

section.title: Assigning users to different roles in OLE
section.para: In OLE, to assign a role to a person, you will use the “Identity Admin” section of the Admin menu. As noted above, there are roles (or non-derived roles) and derived roles. Assigning a non-derived role to a person can be done through the role document or through the person document, see the appropriate sections in this chapter for instructions.

There are also derived roles in OLE inherited from KFS that can be assigned from the user interface and are described in the sections below. The first four listed in this chart are derived roles that you will need to assign in your local institution.:

informaltable.style: border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-layout-alt:fixed;border:none; mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-yfti-tbllook:160;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; mso-border-insideh:.5pt solid black;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid black

para.emphasis: 1) Both have Global versions where changes can be made en masse.

2) There are other derived roles in KIM, most will usually be derived from information about the user on the document - i.e. primary organization. Typically these roles are created by technical staff.
3) Fiscal Officer is the only required role. The Account document cannot be created without it and the Account route node delivered is a required route node.

section.para: The roles above, and many others, are delivered with OLE - you just need to make sure people (staff members) are available in your local system, make assignments, and they are ready to go.

section.title: Fiscal Officer Role
section.para: Each account in OLE is assigned a designated approver called a fiscal officer. This individual is responsible for maintaining the fiscal integrity of an account and is often one of the first approvers to review a document that impacts the account. Most financial processing documents are routed to the fiscal officer for each of the accounts identified in the document.
As an example:
Roberta Renfrow is an Acquisitions Manager. She is responsible for approving purchases for a specific Account BL-1031400. She is the Fiscal Officer for this account.

You assign Roberta to the role of Fiscal Officer by updating the Account document in OLE. You do not need to do anything from the “Identity Admin” section (KIM documents) on the Admin Menu, you just need to update the accounts that Roberta is responsible for approving by making her the Fiscal Officer on the accounts in OLE.

note.para: For more information about the document, see Accounts under the Select and Acquire Module.

section.para: As stated above, every e-Doc that has the Account route node on it (REQ, PO, etc) that uses this account routes to Roberta Renfrow.

section.title: Assigning a Fiscal Officer from an Account

listitem.para: From the Maintenance Menu, click Account to open the Account Lookup.

mediaobject.alt: Account from the Maintenance Menu

listitem.para: Find an Account. Click Edit to open the Account Document.

mediaobject.alt: Account lookup: click edit in the search results
Account document: add the Fiscal Officer under the Account Responsibility tab

note.para: For more information about the Account Document, see Account under the Select and Acquire Module.

section.title: Fiscal Officer Delegate Role
section.para: Let’s take a look at the Fiscal Officer Delegate role. You use the Account Delegate documents in OLE to assign people to this role.
To continue with our previous example:

When Roberta Renfrow is on vacation, she wants Virgie Putman to approve requisitions on her accounts. She wants requisitions to route directly to Virgie for approval so that Virgie doesn’t have to do anything extra. When Roberta returns from vacation, she will remove the delegation by inactivating the Account Delegates.

You can set up Fiscal Officer Delegates for one account and one document at a time from the Account Delegate document or you can use the Account Delegate Global to save time. Roberta has several accounts, so she is going to use the Account Delegate Global. You do not need to do anything from the “Identity Admin” section (KIM documents) on the Admin Menu.

note.para: For more information about the documents, see Account Delegate or Account Delegate Global under the Select and Acquire Module.

section.title: Assigning a Fiscal Officer Delegate from an Account Delegate Global

listitem.para: From the Maintenance Menu, open the Account Delegate Global Document.

mediaobject.alt: Account Delegate Global from the Maintenance Menu

listitem.para: Complete the Document Overview tab

note.para: For more information about the Document Overview tab, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para: Compete the Edit Global Delegate tab.

Note that you can add additional documents. We are just setting up delegation for the Requisition. The Requisition document is a qualifier for this role, it tells Workflow which documents should be checked for delegation. For each Document type you can indicate if the delegation is primary (send the documents directly to this person) or secondary (they must retrieve the document to take action). The other qualifier is Amount - from and to (minimum and maximum amounts for a transaction to route to the delegate).

mediaobject.alt: Account Delegate Global document: Edit Global Delegate tab with a sample delegate added

listitem.para: Add Accounts using the Look Up/Add Multiple Account Lines icon
Note that you could add one account at a time, but that would be pretty time consuming. Accounts are another qualifier for this role, which accounts when used on the Requisition should route.

mediaobject.alt: Account Delegate Global document: Look Up/Add Multiple Account Lines on the Edit List of Accounts tab

listitem.para: Search for accounts belonging to Fiscal Officer “ole-rorenfro”. Use the checkboxes to select specific accounts or the Select/Deselect buttons to check all or remove all checks. Click Return Selected to return to the Account Delegate Global.

mediaobject.alt: Account Delegate Global document: Look Up Screen

listitem.para:
Make any final edits. Click Submit
to route for approval. Once approved, Virgie will be assigned the Account Delegate role.
Note that you can also delete or add accounts if you need to.

mediaobject.alt: Account Delegate Global document: Account Delegate and List of Accounts tabs

section.title: Accounting Reviewer and Organization Reviewer Roles
section.para: The Organization Review document in OLE allows you to make assignments to both the Accounting Reviewer (role OLE28) and the Organization Reviewer (role OLE7). These roles are established when you want to have an approver in addition to the Fiscal Officer. It is different from the Fiscal Officer and the Fiscal Officer Delegate because you can see the assignees in both OLE and KIM. The Fiscal Officer and Fiscal Officer Delegate are derived roles, the only place you can see the assignees in OLE is on the Account and Account Delegate lookups.

note.para: For more information about the document, see Organization Reviewunder the Select and Acquire Module.

section.para: As an example:

The Head Librarian, Michael Baxter, wants to review all Requisitions over $10,000 for the Psychology Department on the Bloomington campus. To accomplish this we will use Organization Review Document in OLE to assign Michael Baxter to this role with the specified qualifiers.

section.title: Assigning Roles from the Organization Review document

listitem.para: From the Select/Acquire Menu, click Organization Review to open the Organization Review Lookup.

mediaobject.alt: Organization Review from the Select/Acquire Menu

listitem.para: Click Create New (top right of the search screen) to open a new Organization Review document.
Complete the Document Overview tab

note.para: For more information about the Document Overview tab, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para: Complete the Organization Review tab.
The Organization Review tab is where we specify which Organization and which Document we want to have Michael approve. The Document and the Organization are qualifiers.
Complete the Chart Code and Organization Code. To specify the document type, click on the Document Type look up icon. The Document Type Lookup screen opens.

mediaobject.alt: Organization Review Role document: Document Overview and Organization Review tabs

listitem.para:
Click the lookup
next to Document Type to find the requisition and return it to the Organization Review document.

mediaobject.alt: Organization Review Role document: Looking up the Document Type

listitem.para: Complete the Assignee/Delegation tab.
The Assignee/Delegation tab is where we specify the Amount, the who (ole-mbaxter), and the what (Approve).

mediaobject.alt: Organization Review Role document: Organization Review and Assignee/Delegation tabs

listitem.para:
Click Submit
. This document does not route.
Michael Baxter has been assigned to the Accounting Reviewer role; let’s see what it looks like in OLE and in KIM.
OLE (Select/Acquire Menu > Reports > Organization Review)

mediaobject.alt: Organization Review Lookup results display the Document type and the Accounting Reviewer

listitem.para: KIM (Admin Menu > Identity Admin > Role
Search for role "OLE28". Click on Accounting Reviewer to open the Role Document Inquiry screen.

mediaobject.alt: Role Lookup results display the Accounting Reviewer role
Accounting Reviewer Role Document

listitem.para: Down towards the bottom, is Michael Baxter with the From Amount set to $10,000:

mediaobject.alt: Accounting Reviewer Role Document displaying the example Michael Baxter

section.title: Permissions, Responsibilities, and Roles Planning
section.para: As you prepare for installation at your own institution, these are the steps you can take to determine how to organize and assign permissions and responsibilities to roles. In this example, we will look at the Deliver module.

listitem.para: Identify the e-Documents, parents and grandparents (Hierarchical Groupings)
You want to do this so that you can assign the same permission for several documents to the parent when that’s appropriate.

tip.para: Using the Routing & Identity Management Document Type Hierarchy (located on the Admin tab) can help because documents are displayed in a hierarchical structure.

listitem.para: Loan*
Return*
Request
Request Re-order*
Patron Bill
Patron
Circulation Desk Mapping, and other maintenance documents

* Note: while Loan, Request Re-order, and Return are not typical e-documents but rather interfaces, they do still require roles and permissions and so are listed here. Deliver Notices is also on the Deliver tab, however it does not have permissions associated with it.
The only Parent for Deliver Documents is "Rice Document"
Identify the permissions that exist for each e-Doc
Remember these are the actions OLE needs to authorize users to perform. Permissions are displayed with details. These define the what, when, and where in KIM.
What – What action occurs: For example, the permission “Post Forgive” has <Action Event> payment to post ‘forgive’ to a charge on a bill.
When – Would explain on what route node an action should take place: <routeNodeName> (These can be seen on Select & Acquire roles).
Where – Where the action occurs: For example, the permission “Update due date” has <View Id> PatronItemView because the permission is used on the Patron e-Doc.

Identify the responsibilities

While no Deliver documents currently route or have responsibilities, locally you may decide routing is needed. Remember that responsibilities differ from Permissions in that they are defining the workflow actions required by a role as opposed to authorizing something in the application itself. Responsibilities also contain details to explain where and when the responsibility should be made. See Responsibility to learn how to create new and modify existing responsibilities.
Identify the Roles
We have identified the e-Docs, the Permissions and the Responsibilities. Now, it’s time to identify the roles. There are two ways to create Roles:
Create each role with each permission explicitly identified or
Nest roles so that roles with additional permissions inherit permissions from more restrictive roles.

note.para: Currently, OLE follows option 1.

section.title: Option 2: Nest roles so that roles with additional permissions inherit permissions from more restrictive roles
section.para: As you could see from the lists above, there are many redundant permissions. Because permissions for Deliver-Circulation are set like this:

mediaobject.alt: Action List Sample with Color Changes Applied

section.para: You may choose to nest roles instead of adding the same permissions to multiple roles. The way nesting works is that if an outer circle, or role, requires the same permissions as an inner circle, than you may assign the outer circle role to the inner circle role and only assign the additional permissions not included in the inner circle. To further explain:

Because the role Super Circulation Supervisor is assigned to the Circulation Supervisor role above and Circulation Supervisor is assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant II and Circulation Desk Attendant II is assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant I, only the permissions unique to Circulation Supervisor need to be listed.

People identified as Circulation Desk Attendant I will be listed individually. Because Circulation Desk Attendant II can also do what Circulation Desk Attendant I can do, their role is also assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant I.
Assignees: user1, Circulation Desk Attendant II

People identified as Circulation Desk Attendant II will be listed individually. Because Circulation Supervisor can do everything that Circulation Desk Attendant I and II can do, their role has been assigned to the Circulation Desk Attendant II role. Because Circulation Desk Attendant II has also been assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant I, Circulation Supervisor will have those permissions as well.

People identified as Circulation Supervisors will be listed individually. Because Circulation Supervisors can do everything that Circulation Desk Attendant I and II can do, their role has been assigned to the Circulation Supervisor role. Because Circulation Supervisor has also been assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant II and Circulation Desk Attendant II has been assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant I, Circulation Supervisor will have all those permissions as well.

People identified as Super Circulation Supervisors will be listed individually. Because Super Circulation Supervisor has been assigned to Circulation Supervisor and Circulation Supervisor has been assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant II and Circulation Desk II has been assigned to Circulation Desk Attendant I, Circulation Manager will have all those permissions as well.

section.title:
Group Group document
Identity Admin submenu group Group document Kuali Identity Management (KIM)
section.para: The Group document allows you to associate persons, roles or other groups with each other in order to assign the same role to all group members.
Groups have no inherent permissions or responsibilities of their own. Only by associating a group with a role do the members of that group become associated with permissions and responsibilities.

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: The Group document includes Document Overview, Overview, Definitions and Assignees tabs.

mediaobject.alt: Group Document

section.title: Overview Tab Group document Overview tab
section.para: This tab identifies the group with a unique system-assigned ID number, a namespace and a name. Each group also has a type that specifies any qualifiers that this group might require.

mediaobject.alt: Group Document: Overview Tab

entry.para: Display only. The unique system-assigned ID number that identifies this group. The system completes this field when you submit the document.
Required. The type of definitions that will be associated with this group. Some group types, such as the Default Type, require no definitions to be collected.

note.para: When creating a new group, you must select the Type before the system can generate the document. See below.

entry.para: Required. An indicator that associates the group with a particular application and module.
Required. The common descriptive name by which this group is known.

Check this box to indicate that this Group is active and is a valid choice for assigning to roles. Uncheck the box to indicate that this group is inactive (no longer valid when making role assignments).
Additional description field for the group.

section.title: Type Name
section.para:
When you click the lookup button
, the system displays the KIM Type Lookup screen. You must search for and select an existing Type in order for the system to generate a new Group document.

mediaobject.alt: Group Document: KIM Type Lookup Screen

section.para: This lookup is used whenever you create a new group or role. The search definitions are explained below.

entry.para: Optional. Select the code identifying the application and module this KIM type pertains to.
Optional. Enter the name identifying this KIM type.
Optional. Enter the unique system-assigned identifying number for this KIM type.
Required (defaults to 'Yes'). Change the default selection to view KIM types that are inactive or are both active and inactive.

section.para: The display of search results includes the same fields as the Lookup screen. To select the type you want to use for your new group, click the return value link for it.

mediaobject.alt: KIM Type Lookup Screen with Sample Results

section.title: Definitions Tab Group document Definitions tab
section.para: This tab contains any definitions specific to this group's type. For example, if a group has a type of Chart and Organization, this tab will record the Chart and Organization values that are specific to this group. In the example below a Chart Code and Organization Code are required for establishing groups of this type. Definitions tab

mediaobject.alt: Group Document: Attributes Tab

section.title: Assignees Tab Group document Assignees tab
section.para: This tab contains the members who belong to this group. It can also be used to add new members or edit the values associated with existing members.

mediaobject.alt: Group Document: Assignees Tab

entry.para: Required. Select the type of member you are adding to this group. Group members can be principals (as defined on the Person document), roles or other groups.

Required. Enter the ID that identifies the member you are adding or use the lookup
to search for and select a valid Member ID. The lookup directs you to the Principal, Group or Role lookup based on your Member Type Code selection.
Display only. Displays the name of the member you've selected.
Optional. To specify the earliest date on which this member is to be considered a valid member of this group, enter a From Date.
Optional. To specify a date on which this member is no longer to be considered a valid member of this group, enter a To Date.

note.para: Note that you cannot delete or inactivate group members. To remove a member from a group enter an Active To Date.

entry.para: Click the Add button to add this member to the group.

section.title:
Permission Permission document
Identity Admin submenu group Permission document Kuali Identity Management (KIM)
section.para: The Permission document allows you to create new permissions or edit existing ones. The Permission Lookup allows you to search for and view existing permissions. You can view summarized information about the permission detail values as well as the roles that are currently associated with this permission.
Only members of KR-SYS Technical Administrator or OLE-SYS Manager role can create or modify Permission documents. These documents do not route for approval.

note.para: Extreme caution should be exercised when modifying existing permissions or adding new ones. Even small changes can have application-wide consequences. Changes should be made only after sufficient testing with your local configuration.

mediaobject.alt: Permission Lookup Screen

entry.para: Optional. To search for a permission based on its template namespace (that is, the name of the application and module to which its template belongs), select the appropriate namespace.
Optional. To search for a permission based on the name of the template it is based on, enter the appropriate template name.
Optional. To search for a permission based on its namespace, select the appropriate permission namespace.
Optional. To search for a permission by name, enter its name.
To search for a permission based on the namespace of the role to which it is assigned, enter the appropriate role namespace.
Optional. To search for a permission based on the role to which it is assigned, enter the appropriate role name.
Optional. To search for a permission based on the principals that currently have this permission through their association with a role, enter an appropriate principal name.
Optional. To search for a permission based on the namespace of groups that have this permission through the group's association with a role, enter an appropriate group namespace.
Optional. To search for a permission based on the name of a group that has this permission through its association with a role, enter an appropriate group name.
Optional. A specific permission detail value associated with a permission
Numerical value of the template namespace

mediaobject.alt: Permission Lookup Sample Results

section.para: The Permission results display contains the fields described in the table below.

entry.para: Actions allow selection of edit or copy for each permission displayed.
The code identifying the application and module the template pertains to. Because templates tend to be general categories, they are often associated with system-level namespaces.
The template the permission is based on. A template usually defines, in a broad sense, what the permission controls. Similar types of permissions share the same template.
The code designating the application and module this permission is associated with.
The descriptive name for this permission. In most cases this will match the Template Name.
Display only. Detailed information that describes the permission and its purpose.
Display only. Detailed information that, in combination with the permission name, defines the permission's function.
For example, if the permission name is 'Initiate Document,' the Permission Detail Values field indicates the specific type of document the initiate permission pertains to.
Permission detail values can include many different types of data. Some common types are defined below.
documentTypeName: The name of the document type associated with this permission.
routeNodeName: The point in a document's workflow routing at which this permission becomes relevant.
routeStatusCode: The routing status that a document must be in for this permission to apply.
propertyName: Often, a field or document element that the permission pertains to.
Lists the namespace and name of roles that have this permission. Click on the linked name to view the Role inquiry.

section.para: To view an Inquiry screen for a permission, select the Permission Name of the appropriate row in the search results. The Inquiry screen contains the same information as the Search Results in a slightly different format.

mediaobject.alt: Permission Inquiry Screen

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: The Permission document includes Document Overview, Permission Info, and Permission Details tabs.

mediaobject.alt: Permission Document

section.title: Permission Info Tab Permission document Permission Info tab
section.para: This tab identifies the permissions with a unique system-assigned ID number, a template, namespace, name and description.

mediaobject.alt: Permission Document: Permission Info Tab

entry.para: Display only. The unique, system-assigned ID number that identifies this permission.
Required. Select the Template this permission is associated with. Templates identify broad permission types.
Required. An indicator that associates the permission with a particular application and module.
Required. A text name identifying this permission.
Optional. Enter a text description of what this permission does.
Required (defaults to 'Yes'). Change the default selection if you wish this permission to be inactive. Inactive permissions will be disregarded by KIM when doing permission checks.

section.title: Permission Details Tab Permission document Permission Details tab
section.para: This tab identifies the permission values that KIM needs to make this permission function. These values vary greatly depending on the type of permission being created. It is highly recommended that users view similar permissions (those with the same Template ID) and discuss Permission Details with technical resources to ensure values are entered correctly.

mediaobject.alt: Permission Document: Permission Details Tab

entry.para: Optional (though most permissions require some details to be functional). Enter the permission details specific to this permission. Details should be entered as the name of the property followed by an '=' followed by the value of the property. When entering multiple details they should be separated by a hard return in the text box, such as:

section.title:
Person Person document
Identity Admin submenu group Person document Kuali Identity Management (KIM)
section.para: The Person document allows you to identify each user to KIM (and, by extension, to OLE). Each Person document includes data about a user's relationship with your institution as well as the roles and groups to which this person belongs.

In KIM a person is a unique combination of an 'entity ID' and a 'principal ID.' The entity ID represents a person with a unique number, and the document associates the entity ID with the user's principal ID number and principal name (often referred to as a user name or user ID). When searching for or working with users in KIM, you usually reference either the principal ID or the principal name. A single entity ID can have multiple principals associated with it, but the base OLE implementation of KIM assumes that each entity ID has only a single principal.

note.para: Note that initiation of the Person document is restricted to members of the KR-SYS Technical Administrator or OLE-SYS Manager role.

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: The Person document includes Overview, Contact, Privacy Preferences, and Membership tabs.

mediaobject.alt: Person Document

section.title: Overview Tab Person document Overview tab
section.para: The Overview tab identifies the person as a unique combination of entity and principal ID. It also contains information about how this person is affiliated with your institution. Two types of affiliations—staff and faculty—contain additional data elements to further define a person's relationship with your institution.

The instructions below assume that you are manually completing this information. Many institutions may want to either have this data fed from an existing person database or simply override this information with existing person data.

mediaobject.alt: Person Document: Overview Tab

section.title: Overview Section
section.para: The first section in the Overview tab is the Overview section.

entry.para: Display only. The unique ID number identifying this person in your database. An individual may have multiple principal IDs but only one entity ID. The base OLE implementation assumes that each user will have only one entity ID and one principal ID.
The system completes this entry automatically when you save or submit the document.

Display only. The unique ID number identifying this principal. Whereas Entity ID represents a unique person, principal represents a set of login information for that person. When selecting a person, you ordinarily reference his or her principal ID.
The system completes this entry automatically when you save or submit the document.
Required. Enter the user name by which this principal is to be identified.
Optional. Enter the password for this principal ID.
Check the box to indicate that this principal ID is active. Uncheck the box to indicate that this principal ID is inactive.

section.para: Use the Affiliations section of the Overview tab to add affiliations for this principal ID. Depending on the affiliation type added, you may need to complete additional fields.

entry.para: Optional. Select the type of affiliation from the list. Options include:

Affiliate: An affiliation for users in your system that are neither employees nor students. Faculty: A faculty employee. Staff: A non-faculty employee. Student: A non-employee identified as a student of your institution.

note.para: Affiliation types of Faculty and Staff require additional information (see below).

entry.para: Required. Select the campus code associated with this affiliation.
Check the box to indicate that this affiliation is this principal's default association with your institution. Each principal must have at least one default affiliation.
Click the Add button to add the affiliation.

section.title: Membership Tab Person document Membership tab
section.para: The Membership Tab allows you to associate a person with groups and roles and, by extension, with KIM permissions and responsibilities. Assigning a person to a role is the most direct way to give a user KIM permissions and responsibilities.

mediaobject.alt: Person Document: Membership Tab

section.para: The tab is divided into three sections, one for managing assignments to Groups, another for Roles, and a third for Delegations.

section.title: Groups Section
section.para: Groups section definition

entry.para:
Optional. Enter the name of the KIM group you want to assign this person to. You can also use the Group lookup
to search for and select a valid value.
Display only. After you select a group to add this person to, the namespace code associated with the selected group is displayed.
Display only. After you select a group to add this person to, the name of that group is displayed.
Display only. After you select a group to add this person to, the type associated with the selected group is displayed.
Optional. If this user's assignment to this group is to be effective as of a certain date, enter that date here.
Optional. If this user's assignment to this group is to terminate as of a certain date, enter that date here.

note.para: There is no way to delete a person's assignment to a group. To remove a person from a group, use this field to specify a date in the past.

entry.para: Click the Add button to add this group assignment.

section.title: Roles Section
section.para: Roles section definition

entry.para:
Optional. Use the Name lookup
to search for and select the role you want to assign this person to.

Display only. After you select a role to assign to this Person record, the system displays the role type associated with the selected role here.
Optional. If this user's assignment to this role is to be effective as of a certain date, enter that date here.
Optional. If this user's assignment to this role is to terminate as of a certain date, enter that date here.

note.para: Note that there is no way to delete a person's assignment to a role. To remove a person from a role, use this field to specify a date in the past.

entry.para: Click the Add button to add this role data.

note.para: When assigning some roles, you may need to supply additional qualifying values that further define this person's assignment. For more information about role qualifiers, see Role.

section.title: Delegations Section
section.para: Delegations allow you to set a user as a primary or secondary delegate for a current member of a role. The delegate has the same permissions as the role member and is able to act on action requests generated for the role member by KIM.
Delegations section definition

entry.para:
Optional. Use the Role Member lookup
to search for and select the role and role member you wish to add a delegation for.
Optional. If this delegation is to be effective as of a certain date, enter that date here.
Optional. If this delegation is to terminate as of a certain date, enter that date here.

note.para: Note that there is no way to delete a person's delegation. To remove a person from a role, use this field to specify a date in the past.

entry.para: Optional. This defines how the delegate will be able to access workflow action requests generated to the delegating role member. Options are 'Secondary' (the user must use the secondary delegate action list filter to view action requests) and 'Primary' (action requests will route directly to the delegate's action list).
Click the Add button to add this delegation data.

section.title: Process Overview
section.para: To give an example of assigning people to different roles, let's look at the Purchasing Processor role. Adding assignees to this role and all other non-derived roles is done the same way in KIM. Different roles will have different qualifiers depending on what should route to this role. This information is usually determined based on information contained in the document. For example, a user’s campus code.
In this example, Derick Cobb has been hired by the Library to handle purchases for the Kokomo campus. He needs to be assigned to the Purchasing Processor role.

There are two ways to add assignees to a role - you can use the Role Document and add the person and their qualifiers or you can use the Person Document and add the Role and Qualifiers to the Person as described below.

section.title: Assigning a Purchasing Processor from the Person Document

listitem.para: From the Admin Menu, click Prson to open the Person Lookup.
Search for "ole-dcobb" (Principal Name). Click edit to open the Person Document.

mediaobject.alt: Person Lookup: Click edit from the seach results list

listitem.para: Complete the Document Overview tab

note.para: For more information about the Document Overview tab, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para: Add the Purchasing Processor (OLE26) role to the Membership tab and click add.

mediaobject.alt: Person Document: Add the role information on the membership tab

listitem.para: Once you click add the role will appear at the bottom of the list of roles. Add the qualifier Campus Code to the role and click add.

mediaobject.alt: Person Document: Once the role is added, add any qualifiers

tip.para: Select Active From/To Dates to assign a role for a set amount of time.

listitem.para:
Click Submit
. This document does not route.

note.para: In OLE 2.0 after clicking Submit and receiving the system response "Document was successfully submitted", if you click Close OLE will ask "Would you like to save this document before you close it?" Select No. If you select Yes, the system will give you a stack trace error. Your changes will be saved in the system.

Additionally, after clicking Save and receiving the system response "Document was successfully submitted", if you click Close OLE will ask "Would you like to save this document before you close it?" Select No. Your changes will be saved in the system.
See OLE-7432 for additional details.

Business Rules Person document business rules
business rules Person document

listitem.para: A person must have at least one affiliation.
Each faculty or staff affiliation must have at least one Employment Information record associated with it.
If a person has any faculty or staff affiliations then one Employment Information record must be marked as 'primary.
Each person must have a default Name record in the Contacts section.
Each affiliation must be associated with a campus.
Each type of contact information can have only one record marked as the default.

section.title:
Responsibility Responsibility document
Identity Admin submenu group Responsibility document Kuali Identity Management (KIM)
section.para: The Responsibility document allows you to create new responsibilities or edit existing ones. The Responsibility Lookup allows you to search for and view existing responsibilities. You can view summarized information about the responsibility detail values as well as the roles with which the responsibility is currently associated.

Only members of KR-SYS Technical Administrator or OLE-SYS Manager role can create or modify a Responsibility document and it does not route for approval. Information about the Responsibility document follows detailed information about the Responsibility Lookup below.

note.para: Caution should be exercised when modifying existing responsibilities or adding new ones. Relatively minor changes can result in disruptions to the workflow of documents if made in error. Changes should be made only after sufficient testing with your local configuration.

mediaobject.alt: Responsibiltiy Lookup Screen

entry.para: Optional. To search for a responsibility based on its template namespace (that is, the name of the application and module to which its responsibility template belongs), select the appropriate namespace.
Optional. To search for a responsibility based on the name of the template it is based on, enter the appropriate template name.
Optional. To search for a responsibility based on its namespace, select the appropriate responsibility namespace.
Optional. To search for a responsibility by name, enter its name.
To search for a responsibility based on the namespace of the role to which it is assigned, enter the appropriate role namespace.
Optional. To search for a responsibility based on the role to which it is assigned, enter the appropriate role name.
Optional. To search for a responsibility based on the principals that currently have this responsibility through their association with a role, enter an appropriate principal name.
Optional. To search for a responsibility based on the namespace of groups that have this responsibility through the group's association with a role, enter an appropriate group namespace.
Optional. To search for a responsibility based on the name of a group that has this responsibility through its association with a role, enter an appropriate group name.
Optional. A specific responsibility detail value associated with a responsibility.

mediaobject.alt: Responsibility Lookup Sample Search Results

section.para: The Responsibility results display contains the fields described in the table below.

entry.para: Actions allow selection of edit or copy for each responsibility displayed.

The code identifying the application and module the template pertains to. Because responsibilities pertain to workflow, most responsibility templates are associated with the KR-WKFLW (Kuali Rice-Workflow) namespace.

The template the responsibility is based on. A template usually defines, in a broad sense, what the responsibility is. Since responsibilities normally are normally associated with action requests for user review, most responsibilities have a template name of 'Review.

The code designating the application and module this responsibility is associated with. This code usually corresponds to the namespace of the document type for which the responsibility generates action requests.
The name of this responsibility. In most cases the responsibility name will be the same as the associated template name ('Review').
Like permission names, responsibility names are not unique. Most OLE responsibilities have a name of 'Review.
Display only. Detailed information that defines what document this responsibility generates action requests for, when the requests are generated and how they are handled by workflow.
Unlike permissions, which sometimes have different detail values, responsibility detail values generally contain the elements defined below.
routeNodeName: The point in a document's workflow routing at which this responsibility generates requests.

documentTypeName: The name of the document type for which this responsibility generates action requests. This value may also be a parent document type, which indicates that this responsibility applies to all child documents that contain the appropriate route node.

actionDetailsAtRoleMemberLevel: A True or False indicator that defines where the system collects details of this workflow action request. If the value is 'True,' the system collects action details when members are assigned to the role. If the value is 'False,' the system collects action details when this responsibility is assigned to a role.

required: A True or False value that indicates whether the system is required to generate an action request for this document type. If the value is 'True' and the document generates no requests associated with this responsibility, then the document will go into exception status. If the value is 'False' and the responsibility generates no action requests, then the document continues to route as normal.
Lists the namespace and name of roles that have this responsibility. Click on the linked name to view the Role Inquiry.

section.para: To view an Inquiry Responsibility Inquiry screen screen for a responsibility, select the Responsibility Name of the appropriate row in the search results. The Inquiry contains the same information displayed in the search results in a slightly different format.

mediaobject.alt: Responsibility Inquiry Screen

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: The Responsibility document includes Document Overview, Responsibility Info, and Responsibility Details tabs.

mediaobject.alt: Review Responsibility Document

section.title: Responsibility Info Tab Responsibility document Responsibility Info tab
section.para: This tab identifies the responsibility with a unique system-assigned ID number, a namespace, name and description.

mediaobject.alt: Review Responsibility Document: Responsibility Info Tab

entry.para: Display only. The unique, system-assigned ID number that identifies this responsibility.
Required. An indicator that associates the responsibility with a particular application and module.

Required (defaults to 'Review'). A text name identifying this responsibility. Note that this is the only valid value for this document. You cannot use the Responsibility document to establish or modify Responsibilities with the name 'Resolve Exception' -these require a technical resource to modify.
Optional. Enter a text description of what this responsibility does.
Required (defaults to 'Yes'). Change the default selection if you wish this responsibility to be inactive. Inactive responsibilities will be disregarded by Workflow.

section.title: Responsibility Details Tab Responsibility document Responsibility Details tab
section.para: This tab identifies the document type and route node associated with this responsibility. It also defines other responsibility information such as whether or not the action details reside at the role member level.

mediaobject.alt: Review Responsibility Document: Responsibility Details Tab

entry.para:
Required. Enter the name of the document type this responsibility is associated with or use the Document Type Lookup
to search for and select a value.
Required. The name of the route node at which this responsibility should be invoked.
Action Details at Role Member Level

Required (defaults to False). Check this box if you want role members associated with this responsibility to be able to define the type of workflow action they will need to take in order to fulfill the action request it generates.
Required (defaults to False). Check this box if you wish documents of this type to go into Exception status if this responsibility does not generate at least one action request.

Optional. In most cases this field should be blank. It can be used as an additional identifier KIM will use to choose the correct responsibility information for a given doc type. The document type must pass the provided identifier to KIM.

This is only used in OLE based data for the routing of group documents. The group type ID is populated here and determines how the document routes (Chart and Organization type groups do organization review routing and default group types do not).

section.title:
Role Role document
Identity Admin submenu group Role document Kuali Identity Management (KIM)
section.para: The Role document allows you to create a new KIM role and edit an existing role. Each role aggregates a specific set of permissions and responsibilities and allows you to assign members to the role. OLE contains many existing roles that your institution may want to use as is, but you may also change existing roles and add new ones by using the Role document.

The purpose of each role is defined by its associated permissions and responsibilities. Roles are classified by types that generally indicate the type of permissions and responsibilities with which they can be associated.

note.para: The process of creating a new type requires technical assistance. Consequently, KIM does not provide an interface for creating role types.

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: The Role document includes Document Overview, Overview, Permissions, Responsibilities, and Assignees tabs.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document

section.title: Overview Tab Role document Overview tab
section.para: This tab identifies the role with a unique system-assigned ID number, a namespace and a name. Each role also has a type which tends to match the types of permissions and responsibilities associated with it.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Overview Tab

entry.para: Display only. The unique, system-assigned ID number that identifies this role.

Display only. Because the role type normally reflects the type of qualifiers this role will need to collect when members are added, this name usually identifies the general types of permissions and responsibilities associated with it.

note.para: When creating a new role, you must select its type before the system will generate the document. See Creating New Roles.

entry.para: Required. An indicator that associates the role with a particular application and module.
Required. The common descriptive name by which this role is known.
Check this box to indicate that this role is active and is, therefore, to be included by KIM when evaluating permissions and responsibilities. Uncheck the box to indicate that this role is inactive.

section.title:
Creating New Roles roles, creating new
KIM Type Lookup screen
Role document Kim Type Lookup screen (creating new roles)
section.para: When you click the Create New button, the system displays the KIM Type Lookup. You must search for and select an existing Type in order for the system to generate a new Role document.

note.para: Note that while the KIM Type Lookup is used when creating new groups and roles, not all KIM types are valid for both. When using this Lookup, you may receive different results depending on the KIM types that are valid for the entity you are working with.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Create New Displays the KIM Type Lookup

section.title: Permissions Tab Role document Permissions tab
section.para: This tab identifies the permissions associated with this role. Permissions authorize specific actions in the system with which they are associated. A role can have any number of permissions (including no permissions) associated with it.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Permissions Tab

entry.para:
To add a permission to this role, enter the appropriate permission ID or search for and select a value using the Permission lookup
.
Click the Add button to add the selected permission to this Role document.

section.para: After you add a permission to the document, the system displays additional information about the permission.

note.para: Permissions cannot be edited via the Role document. Use the Permission document to perform this function.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Permissions Tab with a Sample Permission Added

entry.para: Display only. The Namespace identifies the application and module associated with this permission.
Display only. The unique system-assigned ID number for this permission.
Display only. The descriptive name of this permission. This often identifies, in general terms, what the permission authorizes.
Display only. The document types, tabs and/or fields this permission authorizes. Not all permissions have detail values.
Display only. Indicator showing whether this permission is active within the system or not.
Click the Delete button to remove this permission from the role.

note.para: You may delete a permission only if it has not yet been saved to the database (i.e., you added it to this role but have not yet submitted the document).

section.title: Responsibilities Tab Role document Responsibilities tab
section.para: This tab identifies the responsibilities associated with this role. Responsibilities define the workflow actions that will be requested of the role. A role can have any number of responsibilities (including none) associated with it.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Responsibilities Tab

entry.para:
To add a responsibility to this role enter the responsibility ID or search for and select a value using the Responsibility lookup
.
Click the Add button to add the selected responsibility to this Role document.

section.para: After you add a responsibility to the document, the system displays additional information about this responsibility.

note.para: Responsibilities cannot generally be edited via the Role document, but some responsibilities have associated definitions that you must define at the role level. For information about editing responsibilities, see Responsibility.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Responsibilities Tab with Sample Responsibility Added

entry.para: Display only. The Namespace identifies the application and module associated with this responsibility.
Display only. The unique system-assigned ID number identifying this responsibility.
Display only. The descriptive name of this responsibility. For most Responsibilities the name is 'Review.
Display only. This identifies more specific information about the responsibility. Responsibility Detail Values are formatted in a standard way with the following definitions delimited by commas:
Route Node: The workflow route level at which this responsibility is invoked.
Document Type: The document type for which this responsibility generates workflow requests.

Action Details at Role Member Level: A True or False indicator that defines where the details of this workflow action request are defined. If the value is 'True' then action details will be collected when Members are assigned to the role. If the value is 'False' then the action details must be collected when this responsibility is assigned to a role (see Assigning Action Detail Values.)

Required: Indicates if the routing represented by this responsibility should be required. If this is set to True and the responsibility fails to generate an action request (perhaps because no one is assigned to the associated Role) then the document will go into Exception status. If this routing is optional this value will be False and the document will simply skip this responsibility if no requests are generated.
Display only. Indicator showing whether this responsibility is active within the system or not.
Click the Delete button to remove this responsibility from this role.

note.para: You can delete a responsibility only if it has not yet been saved to the database (i.e., you have added it to this role but have not yet submitted the document).

section.title:
Assigning Action Detail Values action detail values, assigning
Role document Responsibility Action subsection
section.para: When adding a responsibility with an Action Detail Values at Role Member Level value of 'False,' you must complete additional fields in a Responsibility Action sub-section. The system displays this section immediately beneath the responsibility you've just added.

The fields in this sub-section define the type of action requests generated for and the general workflow behavior associated with this responsibility. Entries in these fields cause the system to generate the same type of action requests for all members of this role and handle actions by all members in the same way.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Responsibility Action on the Responsibilities Tab

entry.para: Display only. The namespace and name of the responsibility associated with these action details.
Required. The type of action request that the system is to generate for this responsibility. Options include Approve, FYI and Acknowledge.

Optional. If multiple requests are generated at the route node specified on this responsibility, this value determines in the order in which the system will generate these requests. The system processes requests with lower priority numbers before processing requests with higher numbers. Requests with no number are treated as a priority of 1.

Required. This value determines what happens if multiple members of this role receive the same action request and one of them takes the action. This currently only applies in situations where a single action request is generated to multiple role members (i.e. the action details exist at the role level) or a role is assigned to another role and these nested role members receive an action request. For example, if a role with a responsibility with action details defined at the role level has three members assigned, all of these members receive the action request defined here; this code determines what the system does when one of them takes action on the document.
A value of FIRST indicates that the first role member to take action on the document will automatically clear all the requests for this responsibility that may be in other role member's action lists.
A value of ALL indicates that each role member must take individual action to clear his or her requests.

Check the box to indicate that each user must take this action for this request even if the user has already previously taken action on this document. Leaving the box unchecked allows a request to be immediately fulfilled if the role member has previously taken action on this specific document.

section.title: Assignees Tab Role document Assignees tab
section.para: This tab contains all members who belong to this role. You may also use the tab to add new members and edit the values associated with existing members.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Assignees Tab

entry.para: Required. Role members can be principals (as defined on the Person document), groups or other roles. Select the type of member you want to add to this Role.

Required. Enter the ID of the member you want to add or use the lookup
to search for and select a valid value. The lookup directs you to the Principal, Group or Role lookup based on your Member Type Code selection.

note.para: There is a reported bug that will not allow you to add anything other than a Principal. If you try to add a Role or a Group, the screen never finishes loading (OLE-6771).

entry.para: Display only. Identifies the namespace code associated with this role member. Note that only groups and roles will display a namespace code.
Display only. Identifies the name of the member being assigned to this role.
Optional. Allows you to qualify this member's association with this role by date. Entering a from date will define the earliest date on which this member is a valid member of this role.
Optional. Allows you to deactivate a member's association with a role on a specific date. The date you enter defines the date the user is no longer a member of this role.

note.para: You cannot delete or inactivate role members. To remove a member from a role, specify an active to date.

entry.para: Click the Add button to add this member to the role.

note.para: Additional fields may be required, such as Chart Code or Organization Code, depending on the role type selected.

Note that when assigning roles to other roles (nesting roles nesting roles
roles,nesting ), qualifying values are not required. Some roles in OLE base data contain special logic to derive the required qualifiers from the nested role itself without qualifiers being specified. You may always specify qualifying values for a nested role and should do so unless you know the role being assigned contains logic to derive the qualifiers from the nested role. Roles without the proper qualifiers can cause problems throughout your OLE instance. Please consult with a OLE technical resource if you are unsure of whether or not to provide qualifying values when assigning a role to another role.

section.title: Delegations Tab Role document Delegations tab
section.para: This tab identifies delegates associated with the role. Delegates are users that a member of this role has authorized to have the same permissions and take the same actions as the member is authorized to take.

The Assignees Tab dealing with Delegates is slightly different as detailed in the following table. Note that if the members of a role require qualifying values, the delegation requires these values as well. In most cases, delegates must have the same qualifiers as the role member they are associated with.

mediaobject.alt: Role Document: Delegations Tab

entry.para:
Required. Use the lookup
to search for and return the member of this role you wish to create a delegate for.
Required. Delegates may be principals (as defined on the Person document), groups or other roles. Select the type of delegate you want to add to this role.

Required. Enter the ID that identifies the delegate you want to add or use the lookup
to search for and select a valid value. Note that the lookup will direct you to the Principal, Group or Role lookup based on your Member Type Code selection.
Display only. Identifies the namespace associated with the selected delegate. Note that only delegations to groups or roles will display a member namespace code.
Display only. Shows the name of the selected delegate.
Optional. If you want you can qualify this delegate's association with this role by date. Entering a from date will define the earliest date on which this delegate is a valid delegate for this role.
Optional. Allows you to deactivate a delegate's association with a role on a specific date. The date you enter defines the date on which the user is no longer a delegate for this role.

note.para: You cannot delete or deactivate delegates. To remove a delegate from a role, enter an active to date.

entry.para: Required. Select 'Secondary' or 'Primary. Note that this selection only applies to responsibilities associated with the role and indicates if the delegate will receive documents directly in their action list (Primary) or may choose to view documents in their action list using the secondary delegate list (Secondary).
Click the Add button to add this delegate to the role.

note.para: Additional fields may be required depending on the role type selected.

section.title: Process Overview
section.para: To give an example of assigning people to different roles, let's look at the Purchasing Processor role. Adding assignees to this role and all other non-derived roles is done the same way in KIM. Different roles will have different qualifiers depending on what should route to this role. This information is usually determined based on information contained in the document. For example, a user’s campus code.
In this example, Alta Beal has been hired by the Library to handle purchases for the Bloomington campus so she needs to be assigned to the Purchasing Processor role.

There are two ways to add assignees to a role - from the Role Document you can add the person and their qualifiers (as described below) or you can use the Person Document and add the role and qualifiers to the person.

and click Search.

Click Submit
. This document does not route.

section.title:
Role/Group/Permission/Responsibility Type Role/Group/Permission/Responsibility Type
Identity Admin submenu group Role/Group/Permission/Responsibility Type document Kuali Identity Management (KIM)
section.para: When the user selects the Role/Group/Permission/Responsibility Type option from the Admin menu tab, the system displays the Kim Type Lookup screen. Types are used to associate similar roles, groups, permissions and responsibilities. For example, all roles with the type of 'Campus' will collect a campus code for each member as a piece of qualifying data to tell KIM which campus that member is associated with. New types cannot be created via the interface. Development work needs to occur to make sure that KIM knows how to handle any new type added to the system.

mediaobject.alt: KIM Type Lookup Screen with Sample Search Results

entry.para: Display only. The namespace code associated with this type.

Display only. The descriptive name of this type. Clicking the name takes you to the Type Inquiry and displays the same information available in the lookup plus the name of the KIM service this type is associated with.
The 'service' is the piece of code that tells KIM how to interpret roles, groups, permissions or responsibilities of a given type.
Display only. The unique identifying number assigned to this type.
Display only. Indicates whether this type is active. Inactive types are not eligible for selection when creating new roles, groups, permissions, or responsibilities.

section.title: System Admin Maintenance Documents
section.para: System Admin maintenance e-docs are available via the System Admin submenu on the Maintenance menu.

section.title:
Campus Maintenance CampusMaintenanceDocument
System Admin locations submenu group CampusMaintenanceDocument

para.emphasis:
> Locations
> Campus
> Campus Lookup
> Campus Maintenance Document

section.para: The Campus Maintenance Document is used to identify the different fiscal and physical operating entities of an institution for use in OLE. A campus may be identified as a fiscal entity, a physical entity, or both. Derived from older financial systems, a fiscal campus is not supposed to be allowed on accounts or organizations however in coding KFS, and then transferring to OLE, any campus type is allowed on those documents.

When the user chooses the Campus option, the system displays the Campus Lookup screen. After the user selects a campus or clicks the create new button, the system presents the Campus Maintenance Document.

mediaobject.alt: Campus Maintenance Document

section.title: Edit Campus Tab
section.para: The Campus Maintenance Document includes the Edit Campus tab CampusMaintenanceDocument Edit Campus tab .
In edit mode, the Edit Campus tab presents a display-only set of fields on the left and editable fields on the right in which the user may enter changes.

entry.para: Required. The unique identifying code assigned to a campus.
Required. The familiar name for a specific university campus.
Required. An abbreviated name for a specific campus, used in reports in which space is limited.
Required. Indicates the type of campus. Valid values are:

section.title: Implementation Information
section.para: Campus Maintenance is not to be confused with the Campus Parameter document listed under "Vendor Admin" on the Maintenance tab. The Campus Maintenance document is used in the Chart of Accounts in OLE's financial module and also the KIM module. Alternatively, the Campus Parameter, is only used for purchasing, receiving, and is also found on the Vendor Contract tab. The Campus Maintenance document must exist before creating any Campus Parameter documents.

note.para: For additional information about the Campus Parameter document, see the Campus Parameter section under the Select and Acquire Module.

Required. A familiar name of a specific country.

entry.para: An alternative code assigned to a country.
Indicates whether this country code is active or inactive in OLE. Remove the check mark to deactivate this country code.

section.para: The Postal Code Maintenance document defines the zip code by city and state. When the user chooses the Postal Code option from the Admin menu tab, the system displays the Postal Code Lookup screen. After the user selects a postal code or clicks the create new button, the system presents the Postal Code Maintenance document.

note.para: The user may also enter a city and state to find the associated zip code.

The unique identifying code for the county associated with the zip (postal) code.

section.title:
Affiliation Type Affiliation Type Lookup
System Admin reference submenu group Affiliation Type Lookup
section.para: Affiliation types specify codes and text descriptions for the different types of affiliations that can be associated with a Person record in KIM. These codes may be used for data sorting or retrieval purposes. The Affiliation Type Lookup displays the valid affiliation code types.

note.para: Affiliation types cannot be edited via the interface. Technical assistance is required to add new or edit existing affiliation types.

mediaobject.alt: Affiliation Type Lookup Screen with Search Results Displayed

entry.para: Display only. A unique code that identifies this type of affiliation. The base values are:
AFLT = Affiliate, FCLTY = Faculty, STAFF = Staff, STDNT = Student
Display only. A text description of this type of affiliation.
Display only. An alphabetical character used to determine the order in which the system displays affiliation types in the list.
Display only. Indicates whether this type of affiliation is active (in which case the system displays it in the Affiliation Typelist on the Person document).

section.title:
Campus Type Campus Type Lookup
System Admin reference submenu group Campus Type Lookup

para.emphasis:
> Campus Type
> Campus Type Lookup
> Campus Type Maintenance Document

section.para: When the user selects Campus Type from the Admin menu tab, the system displays the Campus Type Lookup. From this screen, the user may either create a new type or search for an existing type. This defines the valid types of campuses that can be selected when creating a new campus.
After performing a search based on user-specified criteria, the system displays a results table. The user may then choose to edit or copy a retrieved record.
After the user selects create new, edit, or copy, the system displays the Campus Type Maintenance document. This document allows users to add and maintain campus types.

note.para: While anyone can view the current values for campus type, only members of OLE-SYS Manager or KR-SYS Technical Manager roles can create new campus types or edit existing values. This document does not route for approval.

mediaobject.alt: Campus Type Maintenance Document

section.para: The Campus Type Maintenance document includes the Edit Campus Type tab PostalCodeMaintenanceDocument Edit Postal Codes tab .
In edit mode, the Edit Campus Type tab presents a display-only set of fields on the left and editable fields on the right in which the user may enter changes.

entry.para: Required. Enter a code to identify this type of campus.
Required. Enter a descriptive name for this campus type.
